reviewText:
This game is awesome. It features stunning graphics, a perfectly blended score and voice acting far superior to most games I've played in my whole life (really, in my case that means something, gaming since the glorious CBM 64 times!).

The game is so well crafted you could easily find yourself lost in playing it for only enjoying the fabulous scenery. In fact it is so damn good the game could easily feature the Disney logo in front and it would be an honour for the company that brought to us so many lovely and memorable movies (and I'm quite sure it would be an honour for the developer to ... ;).

There is love and workmansship squeezing out of every detail of the setting and aspect of the game. The only letdown is that it's relatively easy, so don't expect something like a Castlevania or Metroid out of it gameplaywise, but keep in mind that this very game here was made merely by one person only during a period of four years devoting all his developing skills to just this one game. And you don't get to see things like this happen very often these days anymore. For 20 years now I always thought that this is a good sign for quality in games and seeing this game now is the proof that my believe is right.

And the gameplay ... omg the gameplay ... To say it in one word it's gorgeos. You can control the game perfectly with whatever input device you throw at it. The player and the enemy animations plus the scrolling are fluid like golden butter in the mildness of a sunny summer's evening driping from a bunch of freshly cutted bread.

For my part I even enjoy the story very much. I can't understand the complains of some of the other reviewers. For a game like this it is absolutely fullfilling all of my deeds I have to a decent action platformer with RPG-elements like Dust is. You got the whole pack here: Tragedy, Revenge, Mystery and Suspense. And that's only the main story line. On top of that there are many sidequests offered by various NPCs from within the games different locations. And the NPCs are so well and lovely implemented in the game, with so much heart that has been put into their design you will have no other choice but to help 'em out.

For me this game is one of the best games I've played for a few years now. The only concern I have about it is that it has an end, and like with everything as good as Dust it will most likely come too soon ... But what the heck ... at least you've got two more difficulty settings if you played it through on normal. And for the not so pro-players amongst us, there is even a Casual difficulty setting so that really every single player can enjoy this game independently from what their gaming skills might be.

If you enjoyed games like Aztaka you should absolutely get this.

If you played this game through and want some more you should probably get Aztaka ... :)

I got my copy of the game on a discount sale but I'd say it's easily worth even the full price.

reviewText:
This was a ridiculously fun game. The gameplay shines as extremely fast paced. You earn experience by chaining up huge combos, ensuring a continual stream of hacking, slashing and causing explosions to fly around the screen. One thing to note is that you may want to consider using a controller rather than a keyboard.

Sadly, the game's storyline is pretty weak and left a lot to be desired - You play as Dust, the mysterious hero who wakes up with (DUN DUN DUUNNNNN) amnesia and ends up finding himself on a quest to save the Moonblood (AKA, reptile) race from genocide at the hands of General Gaius and his legion of racist mammals, learning your destiny and true nature along the way and blah blah blah... it's pretty standard generic fare, and in my opinion, left a lot of important details unspoken that I REALLY wish would have been expanded on. It also creeped me out a bit how oddly sympathetic General Gaius was portrayed despite basically being lizard Hitler. Despite all that, the characters are pretty likable and full of personality, and the voice acting is well done.

Visuals are the other area where this game really shines aside from gameplay. Almost all of the graphics are hand drawn, with the exception of water renderings and Dust's sword (which admittedly causes an odd juxtaposition with his hand-drawn sprites). The locations, although generic (forest level, cave level, snow level, lava level etc), are all beautifully illustrated and provide gorgeous eyecandy.

If you can forgive the weak story in lieu of the strong gameplay, then I highly recomend Dust: An Elysian Tail

reviewText:
I liked and enjoyed this game so much that i ran here to post a reccomendation, i suggest this to everyone that likes a game that can offer a good plot, nice mechanics for being a simple side-scrolling hack n' slash.

Let me explain,
The mechanics and the combat system are very nice, not too difficult to understand, smooth and filled with spectacular effects, but they can be a little repetitive during the end game. The game engine runs smoothly and the graphics are awesome, they're filled with colorful maps, characters and enemies.
The plot and the storyline are good, it's filled with well-made characters with good voices and different personalities, the main character itself is epic.
I enjoyed the soundtrack very much and it is well fitted with the situations, with the scenes and with the different areas of the map.
I liked the puzzles and side-quests too, they can take you some time away because they're not easy to understand, you must explore the map and understand exactly what you must to do to make your way to the game ending.
The only thing that i feel a little bad about is that once you finish the game and the side quests hardly you will play this again because it hasn't a high replay value, you're not going to feel at the same way of your first time on this game.

reviewText:
Not long time ago, in not a far away galaxy, Dean Dodrill creates a beautiful game, with little fairy story - Dust: an Elysian Tail.

We playing as Dust, creature with 2 souls and speaking sword. He has a companion - Fidget, little cute nimbat. Dust should pass hard bloody path in which revealed the mystery of his identity.

Gameplay is pretty simple: kill the enemies, complete the quests, open the treasure chests, lift up your level, collect and buy useful items. And all of it accompanied really beautiful graphics and soundtrack. I can spend many hours looking at the characters and background, Dean make a really great game, I love it.

But the game is very short, bosses are easy to beat (even the General Gaius, last of them) and battles with monsters eventually makes you bored (monsters respawn, when you get back at the section of level).

My verdict: if you like side-scrollers, furries and want to play as a character with amnesia, this game is your choise! Buy it, you will hardly be disappointed.

reviewText: Dust: An Elysian Tail is an fantastic game. Beautiful hand-drawn art, visuals and animations, fantastic soundtrack and voice acting, as well as characters and story. Combat is fluid with every button press and sword swing.\nYour main character, Dust, is an energetic, humorous furry warrior who (like in many games) lost his memory and goes on a quest to find out who he actually is. On this quest he is acompanied by Blade of Ahrah (a talking blade, yes) and Blades diminutive guardian Fidget which makes for a lot of fun throughout the game. Story is beautifuly written and both main and side quests offer you hours and hours of playing without getting bored. Combat style is as many would say is easy-to-learn
date: difficult-to-master" type with usually dozens of enemies on the screen and with many possibilities and tricks makes for a very good combat system.\nThere are some cons here and there like enemies and bosses being very easy early in game (but they get a lot harder in later parts of game and make for formidable opponents)
recommended: some items being overly expensive early on and as much as Dust have nice moves and attacks
hoursPlayed: few more combos or attacks would always be nice.\nAll in all
voteText: Dust: An Elysian Tail is everything you could want in an action rpg

votesHelpful: but to all gamers out there to atleast give it a try.\nMy score for this game is 9.5/10 and I have enjoyed it from beginning to very end and so will you :D"

reviewText:
Simply put, this game is amazing even when it`s tailor-made by one person only (with the help of others though).

First of all, the gameplay mechanic is quite simple, hack and slash your way through hordes of enemies, simple enough. Add that with magic abilities from your furry pal and you can own most of the game. You can upgrade all your equipments except your sword. Why? Well, you`ve gotta play it for yourself to know. The constant changing of environment keeps the game fresh and exciting. The platforming were great and not too difficult. The graphics and visuals reminds me of Okami (in some sense) although the mechanics are completely different. Every character in this game has a life. By that I mean that each of them has a distinct characteristic in them, the pride of a artist, the affection of one to another, the hatred of other races and so on.

However, the lack of varieties in your ways of attacking makes it a bit dull. Often at times I found myself mashing the same button to clear waves after waves of enemies. Save points are sometimes scarce and you`ll be praying one appears in front of you before you get KO-ed and restart from way back. The boss battles are quite disappointing though, constanly being exploited by me lol. Unlike any other games, this game doesn`t have any replay value. It doesn`t even give you the chance to explore after endgame.

Although this game certainly had some flaws. I really still enjoyed it :)

8/10

reviewText:
How good this game was really surprised me, it's a really cool platformer.
The combat is fluid, everything is easy to understand. And eventhough you only have one weapon through the entire game, it doesn't really matter as you can do a couple of moves and have your friend, Fidget, attack as well. The acting in this is alright, the story is honestly a bit meh to me. Your sidekick Fidget is either going to annoy the hell out of you or be adorable - to me she was adorable.

I also really love the artstyle of this game, which surprised me a lot since I'm not too into anime. It's really beautiful and unique, not the kind of game that I'd normally play. The game is a bit short though, I finished the main questline in about roughly 13 hrs, to complete the entire game it'd probably take about 16-17 hrs. All in all, I'd recommend this game. Would I pay full price for it though? Probably not, due to the short amount of gameplay. But if it comes on sale again, I'd definitely pick it up if I were you.

reviewText:
I love MetroidVania type games. You start out weak, but as you progress, you get more powers to play with and more strength, and you can go back to enemies that gave you trouble early on and give them what-for.

Dust: An Elysian Tail pulls that off really well. The game gives you a robust combo system to fight with from the start, so you don't have to wait 5 hours to really feel epic. The gameplay in general is such that every fight feels mostly fair, since with some finesse you can combo your way to victory.

As for the art style, I can say it's not for everyone. I quite enjoyed the whimsical nature, but it's probably not for everyone.

The one problem that I had is that it's really short. You could burn through it in 6-8 hours, and it has little replayability, since you explore pretty much the entire map by the end. Completionists would have a bit more, but I left wanting more.

reviewText:
Here's a game that made it into my top favorite games of all time

Dust have been (aside from voice acting, soundtrack and parts of the story) fully developed by Dean Dodrill, both programming and graphics.

Speaking of graphics, the game looks fantastic. The drawn graphics are even more beautiful than Rayman Legends.

The music is wonderful. HyperDuck Studios did a very good job at creating those long, varied tracks. The voice acting is good, not the best out there but good.

The game is a mix of action, platforming and RPG and it works really well. The combat is quite simple, but fun. The exploration is fun too. There are quite a few sidequests as well. The gameplay works really well, and the fact it was programmed by a single person is simply impressive.

The story is enjoyable and quite well-written. The character are likeable. Despite the quite serious tone, there's a lot of humour and even some references to other games (like that stupid tornado thing from Castlevania 2). The game is a little short, but if you're a completionist and want to clear everything, it might take about 15-20 hours, otherwise... about 10.

Dust: An Elysian Tail is a wonderful indie game, really worth its price.
Pros: Graphics, Music, Fun Gameplay, Fidget
Cons: A little too short

reviewText:
Dust: An Elysian Tail შექმნაზე ფაქტიურად ერთი ადამიანი მუშაობდა. დინ დოდრილი თამაშის დაპროგრამირების პარალელურად, საკუთარი ძალებით ქმნიდა ვიზუალურ მხარეს, იგონებდა დიალოგებს, აკეთებდა პრერსონაჟების ანიმაციას, ხოლო გარკვეულ ეტაპზე გახმოვანებაზეც და მუსიკაზეც თვითონ ზრუნავდა. მაგრამ როგორც ჩანს თავისი შესაძლებლობებით ყველაფერს ვერ გასწვდა, რადგან გმირები პროფესიონალი მსახიობების მიერ იქნენ გახმოვანებულნი, ხოლო მუსიკის შესაქმნელად დადრილმა შეილება არც ისე ცნობილი, მარგამ საკმაოდ ნიჭიერი ადამიანი მოძებნა.

An Elysian Tail მთავარი პერსონაჟი - სხვადასხვა ფერის ნაჭრებით შემოსილი, კატის მაგვარი არსება დასტი, - გონს რაღაც ზღაპრული ტყის შუაგულში მოდის და მის გარშემო იმწამსვე რამდენიმე საინტერესო ფაქტი ხდება. პრიველი - მას ანეზია აქვს, მეორე - მას ბუჩქებიდან გამოვარდნილი ხმალი ელაპარაკება, მესამე - ერთი შეხედვით უვნებელი ბანკის კოკაკოლისხელა რიჟა ცხოველი ფიზიკური ზეწოლით ემუქრება. მოცემული სპონტანური შეხვედრა კი საბოლოოთ მათი დამეგობრებით სრულდება და დასტის, ლაპარაკის მოყვარული ძველი ხმლის ეჰროს და მათი ერთგული, ჰენტაიდან გამოქცეული მეგობრის საიდკიკის საოცარ თავგადასავალში გადადის. ჩვენი გმირს საკმაოდ დიდი გზააქ გასავლელი, მას ხომ ჩაგრულების დაცვა, მთავარი ბოროტმოქმედის დამარცხება და საკუთარი წარსულის გარკვევა მოუწევს.

მთელი Dust: An Elysian Tail დინის ხელით არის დახატული, რაც პირველივე შეხედვიდან იგრძნობა - ავტორს ზღაპრული სამყაროს ყველა დეტალი დიდი სიყვარულით აქვს შექმნილი. თამაშის სამყარო რამდენიმე ძირითად ტერიტორიად იყოფა, რომლებიც უნიკალური ლოკაციებით, ქვესთებით და საიდუმლოებებითაა სავსე. მდელოებზე დრაკონის ბატყებთან და ხვლიკების მსგავს ხულიგნებთან მოგიწევთ ბრძოლა, გამოქვაბულებში - მფრინავი კიბორჩხალები, მთებში - თოვლში მოთამაშე მგლები, სასაფლაოზე - მწვანე და ლურჯი ზომბები. თამაშს მარტივი და ამასთანავე საკმაოდ ღრმა საბრძოლო სისტემა გააჩნია: გვაქს საბაზისო პრიომები, რომლების მეშვეობითაც რთული და სანახაობრივი კომბოები კეთდება. Dust ფსევები აშკარად საკულტო საიდსქროლერებიდან Metroid და Castlevania-დან იზრდება. არა იმას არ ვამბობ, რომ დადრილი მათ დაკოპირებას ცდილობს, ნამდვილად არა. An Elysian Tail - აღიარებული კლასიკისადმი საპატივსაცემო ჟესტს წააგავს.

reviewText: Honestly, I'm not sure why I'm even bothering to write a review of Dust: An Elysian Tail.\nEverybody already knows that this game is awesome. Tens of thousands of reviews have been posted. I believe that everything that needs to be said about the game, has probably already been said. Furthermore, I can't make up a bunch of complaints and flat-out lie, just so I can be Mr. Contrarian". If were to present an argument that Dust isn't really all that great
date: first I'd have to convince myself
recommended: and that isn't happening.\n\nWhy do I think Dust is great? It's mainly due to the controls and level-design. If you've played this game
hoursPlayed: then you're well-aware of the protagonist's abilities
voteText: particuarly his uh... tornado spin?(Press Y button while in mid-air*). This move homes in on enemies
helpfulPercent: and can even cause Dust to be launched miles into the air
votesHelpful: if he's aiming for a flying enemy. A neat trick is using a Lightning storm
votesTotal: then following with the tornado
votesFunny: as enemies are lifted into the air by the electricity. There's a certain joy to be found in soaring through the sky
commentsCount: even when there isn't an incentive (such as treasure).\n\nAt the same time
column16: Dust's ability to practically fly isn't a hindrance to the level-design. There are a few shortcuts
column17: and maybe even a sequence break or two
column18: but there's nothing that comes off as really awkward. Due to Dust's mobility
column19: he doesn't really work in a pixel-precise-platformer. Thus
column20: all of the platforms in this game - moving or otherwise - are wide enough. I'd say that on average
column21: they're more than two "Dusts" in width.\n\nNow hang on a second. How does one measure "Dusts"? In platformers
column22: it's always important to consider the character and their relationship with the world. Take Super Mario Bros. 1 for example. The smallest block in SMB1 is only slightly wider than Mario. This gives players just enough time to react
column23: but they don't have to constantly measure their jumps. Having to adjust your landing for every single jump not only affects the pacing of the game
column24: but it also becomes tiring for the player. Another example is the first Sonic the Hedgehog game. Sonic is a faster character
column25: so the platforms he lands on tend to be twice as wide as he is. There's more that could be said here
column26: but it would all be irrelevant to this review of Dust: An Elysian Tail. In short
column27: platforming in this game works
column28: because the player has enough freedom to move around.\n\nThe combat also benefits from all of the mobility. There are many tools to play around
column29: and even if they're at times unnecessary
column30: they're still appreciated. If a player wants to tornado through all of the enemies while tossing storms everywhere
column31: that's fine. They can just as easily stay on the ground
column32: and decimate everything with the sword alone. Switching between multiple styles is seamless
column33: and it works wonderfully.\n\nOh and if you haven't noticed this before. In the final area
column34: if you perform an air-grab on the flying ships
column35: the game pauses for a suitably epic second. The game doesn't do this for any of the other enemies (even the final boss)
column36: and that's really cool.\n\nOther than that... Well
column37: I'm afraid I don't have anything else to add. This is a superb game

reviewText: Dust is a 2D action-exploration game in the famed 'Metroidvania' style, with some pretty cool elements to it. It actually reminds me a lot of Muramasa: The Demon Blade" (if you've ever played or heard of that). As with Muramasa
date: the first thing you will notice are the stunning hand-drawn visuals and animation. The look of the characters and backgrounds during gameplay are quite beautiful. Additionally
recommended: the characters all have detailed animated portraits that appear on-screen during conversations. It just looks fantastic all around. The characters themselves are all pretty good
hoursPlayed: assuming you can stomach a cast full of anthropomorphic animals (and a seriously cutesy flying bunny-type-thing sidekick). The voice acting and plot are generally good as well. Gameplay consists of 2D sword combat with light platforming elements. The combat also has a few cool twists - your sidekick has projectile attacks that can be combined with a special sword technique
voteText: resulting in some spectacular combos and on-screen fireworks. It all looks and feels really cool once you get the hang of it. Eventually you will become just  ridiculously powerful
helpfulPercent: making the game very easy
votesHelpful: but it's still good fun. As with similar games

reviewText:
To be honest, this is one of the best games I've ever played so far.

Initially, I was rather skeptical of how this game will appeal to me as I was never a big fan of hack & slash games and the slow and mundane plot in the first few minutes almost confirmed my suspicion. Thankfully, things caught up quickly and soon I found myself lost in the world of Dust.

The artworks and soundtracks used in this game are top-notch from the start to the end. I thoroughly enjoyed the aesthetical aspects of the game and I applaud the developers for putting their efforts. The story as a whole was excellent and the characters are among one of the best written ones I've seen.

You'd need to play this with a gamepad though as playing on a keyboard may not be ideal in numerous fights and can give a different (or perhaps  a less enoyable) experience as a result. Anyway, there is also a pretty good variety of combat skills to choose from and you will be able to use them in various situations such as searching for treasures or going against different enemies. It's a rather big world out there so do try to explore all parts of the map.

The only negative I could think of were the lags during the cutscenes. I've already experienced it twice during my playthrough and I had to reload a save and complete the level/fights again to watch the cutscene once more. Not a potential game-breaker but they can be annoying.

In a nutshell, I highly recommend people to try this game out. I got it during the sale so it was definitely worth the money. However, even without any discounts, its price is still rather acceptable for a game of its calibre. An amazing game that will give you a whole lot to think about when you play it.

Ashes to ashes, dust to dust!

reviewText: This has to be one of my favorite independent games out there today. While it took me a moment to adjust to the type of animation and voice acting, I ended up really enjoying the characters, story and combat. reviewText:
I will make this short and sweet because this game is just that much fun to play. The story is dramatic has good and funny voice acting,subtitles,characters,etc. The game is extremely colorful is full of great animations and unique monsters and bosses to fight. The locations are varied from woods to frozen mountains which themselves draw you into the game even further.

The combat is simple and fantastic, you gain new abilities along the way as you play.There are a good number of difficulty settings to choose from.The game has a good number of completetionist type achievements and secrets to find for you 100% players.As far as gameplay length, you could beat it in about 10 - 15 hours depending on how much exploring/secret finding you do.

I am a big action adventure and action rpg fan so for me when looking at all the animal themed characters I was a bit cautious thinking I was in for a kiddy adventure but it turned out to be a real gem. I hope the developer makes another Dust game I enjoyed this just that much.

reviewText:
Dust: An Elysian Tail is an action adventure side scrolling game that has strong story element. If you're looking for the game as such with fair pricing then this is a good one for you.

Playing the game from the start to finish is truly a rewarding experience. The story writer knew how to make an engaging background history, to implementing the plot through the game progression (and of course having full voice cast and interesting character developments). And I gotta say, the voice actors did make a wonderful job. They could show that a voice can deliver strong emotion throughout the game. Moreover, the ending truly was well written, and a strong point to playing Dust: AET until the finish.

Graphic is is is,.... bad... for furry chars and cartoon haters. Ha. Well no, I'm kidding, the graphic is an incredible touch. I love how they designed the levels and the characters. Dust is cool and tough, Fidget is irritating when she starts to whine but she's especially endearing to see. The animation overall and the level designs are flat out gorgeous, full with lightnings in battle and vibrant colors.

Gameplay, though, is a bit too easy and repetitive. Being an 'easy' side scroller platformer, you literally can overwhelm enemies with Fidget + Arrah's combos and that's all you need to win thru the levels. That's with the hardest difficulty btw. Bosses can be a bit tough, but unlike we have seen on other platformers. Once you know how to block and spam the combos, the game's piece of cake. A bit skill is required when playing the challenges - but it's a sidequest anyway.

Other Side Quests, sadly, don't offer much added value. There are maybe 20 or so, but none of them are memorable for me. Mainly just give you some small rewards and a joy knowing you've completed what the game has to offer.

There's a small RPG element - mainly you can level up Dust (and get him extra HP/stats) and equip armors on him. Blade is not replaceable - you can only arm Arrah, the rest is replaceable. Not much I can say, it's kinda shallow mechanic as there's not enough varieties on armors to make it interesting. Just equip the best ones and you're set.

As always, playing with xinput based controller for all Microsoft-related games is recommended. The button mappings feel natural, so there's no need to mess around.

Game length is a bit short for my preference - only about 10-15 hours even for completionist. Being short, and of course the major lacking point is replayability.

My recommendation would be to pick this game up. Can't go wrong playing Dust - it's one of great indie games that everyone must play.

reviewText: Surprisingly good Metroidvania-styled game, but not without some flaws.  The secondary characters are often flat out ugly and the voice acting quality varies, but the central gameplay is simple and works very well, and the scenery is drop dead gorgeous in most places.  If you're in for the completionist factor. there's many treasures and power-ups to find scattered throughout the games maps (And offers a decent map system to make sure you know if there's a save point/merchant/unfound treasure in  your location) and some bonus trials to test how well adapted to the game you've become.  There's still a lot of care that went into making the game and it shows, and worth picking up on sale or at full price.

reviewText:
Dust has truly captivated me. Not only the character but the game as a whole.
Dust as a character is a young man struggling with his past, present and future. He wakes up not being able to remember who he is or how he got there, thus starting a journey in the search of those lost memories. Sounds quite cliche, but it has been fabulously executed, exceeding my story-related expectatives.
Dust as a game is impressive. The story is simple but deep, everything you do and everyone you meet have something to do in this game, the backgrounds and BGM are breathtaking and the gameplay is intuitive and absolutely great. Even the english dubbing has been properly done. The various side quests it includes (Cirelian Trials, secondary missions, finding treasures and friend cages, finding materials for building your own equipment, etc) add up to the game experience.
A must-play game. Give it a try and you'll be fascinated by the beauty it holds.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game made me cry like a babby which is usually a sign of a really great story.

The controls are a little more difficult with mouse and keyboard and you would benefit from a controller, however I did 112% this game with mouse and keyboard so it's not impossible or anything like that! (In fact in you regularly play platformers with mouse and keyboard then you're probably fine.)

Overall though, the game is really awesome and fun to play. There's plenty of exploring you can do if you want to find all the treasures in this game (it's definitely worth finding the hidden friends for health bonuses). The backtracking for items may annoy some people but I always found it a great oppurtunity to level grind. While it probably helps to do so, the bosses are typically pretty easy so that you don't have to grind. I played on Normal mode and the game was easy enough that I didn't get too frustrated but not so easy that I felt bored. (I plan on trying the harder modes next). Game has a ton of replayability with skippable cutscenes so if you're not into watching them more than once, hooray for you!

Overall I really recommend everyone at least give this game a try, especially if you like platformers or games that you can explore.

reviewText:
So after 2 and a half years of development, we'd finally get this game: Dust: An Elysian tail.

And please tell me if you get the gabe newell reference, but this game was worth the wait in every way.

Throughout the game, i'd search for plotholes and flawed gameplay mechanics, and needsly to say, i couldn't find any.
Dust's controls are the opposite of stiff. The game is really responsive to controls, and it leads to some fun platforming and fast-paced gameplay. And while this game does have a rush bros disease of slow walking and fast rolling, I had an easy time ignoring it to the game's combat.

Not only are you given a however small variety of attacks to dish out pain with, there's loads of combos that you can test yourself to execute and memorize with your keyboard, and you get rewarded for each combo. Not only do you get extra experience, you also get achivements, and your enemies of course die faster. While that does sum it up, this game also has its way of disapointment.
At the beginning of the game, you're given the blade of Ahrah, Fidget, And dus'ts glorious control to utilize and THATS. IT.
Later in the game, you're informed ahrah is only ONE of the blades of elysium; Why couldnt we find and use the others? I wouldve liked more variety than just being stuck with 2 weapons to use. Fidget got more than one mode of attacking, why cant we?

Gameplay aside, the graphics, which are hand drawn by the way look GLORIOUS. They dont cause any eyestrain and there isnt a spam of color palette like rush bros had. The game is really pretty to look at and i hope you buy it for that reason.

Now, lets go to the plot. In the beginning you see an unknown warrior charging through a variety of people for an unknown reason, and later find out he's killed by a child. In the next scene, you see our main character, dust, kneeling in the middle of an unknown forest. This is the game's first point of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ you off. You know why? THERES NO REAL CUTSCENES UNTIL NEAR THE END OF THE GAME. Otherwise, all you get is pictures that might as well mimic a slideshow along with text, it really made me depressed toward how such good artwork was put to waste. Anyway, we're introduced to our 3 protagonists, dust, fidget, and the blade of ahrah, which as i said earlier is the main weapon you'll be using throughout the game. We then see that dust has forgotten his past and that he summoned ahrah for yet another unknown reason. Dust doesnt even know why he did it, but he chooses to ignore it and go on a quest to find out more of his past, kill a bunch of racist knights, and simply bring justice where justice is needed with the help of fidget and the blade of ahrah.
This is why i like indie games like this, they keep the plot simple and fast to keep the player wanting to play their game. You might call it lazy, but it works.

So after all that said, I do like this game for a variety of reasons, (One i'd rather not say) And also, I think that this game has perfect potential and setup for a sequel. If there were a game called Dust 2 (No pun intended), I really hope they'd keep what made this game good and add onto it.

Don't hesitate to buy it. I bought it while it was 80% off, but it's still worth every cent.

I finished it on medium in about 11 hours with a level of 41 and a few sidequests remaining.

Hardcore is worth its name. Bosses tend to 1-hit you and small creeps still finish you off in 2-3 hits, giving you a real challenge. Dodging will be most important which results in Aerial Dust Storm becoming your best friend.

reviewText:
This is a game that knows exactly what it wants to be and delivers it in style. A straightforward, side-scrolling platformer with simple button-mashing combo-style hack n' slash combat, pretty graphics, and a relatively interesting storyline. It's got a very stereotypical anime-esque appearance, but there's beauty in the simplicity of the game. It's extremely well developed, easy to pick up and play, and nicely eyecatching. The animation is wonderfully smooth, with very subtle background effects, and a wide variety of environments to move through as you open up more of the wider map.

I tend to think of this game as being a bit simple, but it's a work of art and it's hard to believe that it was entirely the product of one person. It must have been a labour of love, and that effort shows through. Dust is an interesting character and, almost despite myself, I became engrossed in his story and the way in which it unfolded. I was expecting something very basic and repetitive as this is a 2D platformer I bought during the sale, mainly because I'm a sucker for pretty artwork in games. I didn't expect much beyond a couple of hours of simple gameplay and levelling up a few times before polishing off a boss and ending the game all in time for tea.

A week later, after running through the game twice (I upped the difficulty level the second time around) and earning all of the achievements, proved me totally wrong. At first I was skeptical; I found the characters to be a little bit twee and stereotypical, but as they and the story line developed I got hooked. It's suitable for all ages so don't expect any gore or adult themes, but there's a certain appeal in the innocence of the game; it's certainly not boring, and there are enough challenges and changes to keep you interested despite the fairly repetitive nature of platform gaming. It may appear cartoonish but there are some serious moral themes discussed and life lessons to be learnt. Picking up new abilities throughout the game gets you returning to previous maps to complete things you couldn't do earlier in the game, which nicely prevents it from being a linear run-through from one level to the next.

It's hard to criticise this game because it doesn't promise any more than it delivers. You don't feel short-changed by the simplicity of the game play or the slightly cutesy" characters. It's easy to play through
date: which might be disappointing if you're looking for more of a challenge. It is fairly repetitive but the enemies do get tougher as the game develops
recommended: matching your character's development. The challenge arenas are the only places where you can really push your skills to try to get that elusive four-star rating.\n\nThe other downside is the boss fights - it's a button-masher so just keep hitting the combos for long enough and the boss goes down
hoursPlayed: it's as simple as that. But again
voteText: it's hard to criticise because the game delivers exactly what it promises. It's enjoyable but not astonishing. I recommend it as a pleasant and pretty game to play
helpfulPercent: a nice bit of simple escapism that isn't going to challenge or frustrate you."

reviewText:
I don't normally do Steam reviews, but for this game I had to make an exception.

For quite a few years now, I've found that today's games often feel stale and have lost a part of what makes them fun. I can't quite put my finger on why, but I do know that whatever it is that's missing has been revived in Dust: An Elysian Tail. I haven't found quite as much enjoyment out of a game since Oblivion, and Dust may even replace it as the #1 game I've ever played, in my book.

I thoroughly enjoyed everything that the game has to offer. The gameplay is fun: racking up awesome combos while smashing through groups of enemies is quite satisfying, and I found the game is at times challenging but never too hard nor too easy (based on my playthrough on Tough difficulty). The RPG elements help balance things but aren't at all too prominent or overpowering. The art is stunning, full of colour and atmosphere. The voice-acting, in my opinion, is excellently performed and the story is unique and quite touching. The soundtrack is amazing and each track matches perfectly with it's respective environment (I immediately had to buy the official soundtrack afterwards). Overall, an incredible amount of attention to detail has gone into Dust, and a level of polish you don't often find in the industry these days.

After completing the main storyline, I went for 100% completion of the game (well, 116% or whatever it goes up to), not only for the obvious challenge, but also because it was simply fun to keep playing. I've got a lot of unfinished or half-arsed playthroughs sitting in my library because properly completing them just feels tedious and like a waste of time. This definitely isn't the case here and it took me back to those classic childhood games I could just keep playing for hours until I had explored every location and collected every item on offer.

In terms of negatives, the only ones I experienced are very minor. Occasionally an item may glitch into a wall with no way to get it out, but it rarely happened and was no big deal. Also, out of the 20 or so hours in the game it did crash twice – thankfully, though, the autosave system was there to minimise the amount of progress lost from those unfortunate times. None of these issues are at all game-breaking and don't really taint the game in any way, however. I personally don't think there are any major flaws at all with the game.

Considering everything, I'm blown away that the entire basis of Dust was designed and programmed by just one person. It's quite clear that he understands video games and what they're truly about. I definitely recommend this game to everyone – even at full-price it's totally worth it – and you should at the very least give it a try. Not doing so would be a disservice to yourself as a gamer.

reviewText: What can I say that hasn't been said about this game? Coming from someone who has yet to play Castlevania or Metroid for that matter, I found this to be an amazing game. The soundtrack and the visuals are outright gorgeous. The story is also a great tale to tell; dark, yet humorous at the same time. Not only that, but the characters are also great, varying in many memorable personalities. I don’t mind the choice of art used, especially as I feel it would change the story too much if it was otherwise. My only problem with the game is that the combat can be a bit repetitive at times, but not too much, thankfully. This is literally why I am going to learn about programming; if one man can create nearly everything aside from the music and voice acting, and turn out something that gets such ratings as it got (9-10/10’s), this paves the way for others to do so too. I completely recommend this, as it serves not only as a great game, but as a pillar for others to follow their dreams as well. Thank you, Dean Dodrill; for everything.

reviewText: This game is a truly amazing piece of work.  Its story is compelling, engaging, and touching on many levels; the art is beautiful and brilliant in every area, never once lowering in quality.  Every second of this game made me want more and more of it right up to the climax, and I can't wait to see what he makes in the future!  References to other games abound, but never do they go overboard or make the game any less enjoyable, remaining subtle enough they're easy to overlook at first, then that 'ah-HAH' moment makes it all worthwhile.  I cannot recommend this game enough for anyone who enjoys platformers and terrific story.

reviewText:
So after 2 and a half years of development, we'd finally get this game: Dust: An Elysian tail.

And please tell me if you get the gabe newell reference, but this game was worth the wait in every way.

Throughout the game, i'd search for plotholes and flawed gameplay mechanics, and needsly to say, i couldn't find any.
Dust's controls are the opposite of stiff. The game is really responsive to controls, and it leads to some fun platforming and fast-paced gameplay. And while this game does have a rush bros disease of slow walking and fast rolling, I had an easy time ignoring it to the game's combat.

Not only are you given a however small variety of attacks to dish out pain with, there's loads of combos that you can test yourself to execute and memorize with your keyboard, and you get rewarded for each combo. Not only do you get extra experience, you also get achivements, and your enemies of course die faster. While that does sum it up, this game also has its way of disapointment.
At the beginning of the game, you're given the blade of Ahrah, Fidget, And dus'ts glorious control to utilize and THATS. IT.
Later in the game, you're informed ahrah is only ONE of the blades of elysium; Why couldnt we find and use the others? I wouldve liked more variety than just being stuck with 2 weapons to use. Fidget got more than one mode of attacking, why cant we?

Gameplay aside, the graphics, which are hand drawn by the way look GLORIOUS. They dont cause any eyestrain and there isnt a spam of color palette like rush bros had. The game is really pretty to look at and i hope you buy it for that reason.

Now, lets go to the plot. In the beginning you see an unknown warrior charging through a variety of people for an unknown reason, and later find out he's killed by a child. In the next scene, you see our main character, dust, kneeling in the middle of an unknown forest. This is the game's first point of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ you off. You know why? THERES NO REAL CUTSCENES UNTIL NEAR THE END OF THE GAME. Otherwise, all you get is pictures that might as well mimic a slideshow along with text, it really made me depressed toward how such good artwork was put to waste. Anyway, we're introduced to our 3 protagonists, dust, fidget, and the blade of ahrah, which as i said earlier is the main weapon you'll be using throughout the game. We then see that dust has forgotten his past and that he summoned ahrah for yet another unknown reason. Dust doesnt even know why he did it, but he chooses to ignore it and go on a quest to find out more of his past, kill a bunch of racist knights, and simply bring justice where justice is needed with the help of fidget and the blade of ahrah.
This is why i like indie games like this, they keep the plot simple and fast to keep the player wanting to play their game. You might call it lazy, but it works.

So after all that said, I do like this game for a variety of reasons, (One i'd rather not say) And also, I think that this game has perfect potential and setup for a sequel. If there were a game called Dust 2 (No pun intended), I really hope they'd keep what made this game good and add onto it.

reviewText:
-Quick Review-
Dust: An Elysian Tail is a 2D Side Scrolling action RPG game, which has great voice acting, and a nice quest system that you can play through in a little less than a day.
WARNING: Make sure to save, and not trust the Autosave. The game autosaved over my original copy; I had thought that it was my own save that was updating… this was regrettably not the case. Good bye days worth. Please learn from my mistake.

-Detailed breakdown review-
Story:  Dust: An Elysian Tail starts off very confusing, the story just kind of drops you into the game and says “Hey, you’re the hero, here’s a talking sword and an annoying fairy thing, go save the word!” Now that I think about it, this isn’t really an uncommon trait in video games.
I won’t spoil the story, but I like how the main character looks, the game is very Asian-cultured,  you have your annoying side-kick who just makes your character look better, it has all it needs to have to be a good game… The only down side is that the game goes by really fast.

Game Play:  The game play starts out very fast paced, I knew before I left the starting zone that I was going to enjoy it. The game is based on gaining exp through “combo’s” which you obtain through getting hits on enemies. You’ll figure out neat ways to go about doing this while you play the game and unlock new abilities.
Fidget (The side-kick / flying wombat / fairy-thing) throws magic, Dust uses a Magic sword and you use those two in collaboration in the air or on the ground. That’s what the game comes down to. Knowing when to fight in the air, and how and when to fight on the ground.

Achievements: The achievements on this game are fun. I started the game right away on Normal difficulty, got nearly everything then reset my game and descided to replay on tough to get the final few achievements I missed.
When I started the game on Normal I was very over confident and thought I could just zip through the game without needing to learn where my heal button is… That didn’t work out so great, so it’s not “easy” but it’s not “Super Meat Boy”. Most of the achievements can be obtained relatively easily once you’re familiar with the game.

Price: Dust: An Elysian Tail at normal price is going for $14.99, I would say that the game is priced fairly for the quality you will get. I only put 22 hours into the game, but I did rush a bit and had to look up a guide for the “find all your friends” achievement… The price might still be a bit high for someone with a strained check book.
As I say on most of my reviews, you may want to wait for this game to go on sale before you buy it, but it is definitely worth buying. Additionally it is currently in the Humble Bundle for the next eleven days! You might want to jump at the chance to get it now with a few other indie games: https://www.humblebundle.com/

Conclusion: I enjoyed this game, I felt that I got my money’s worth out of it, the story was excellent, the quality was impressive, the game play was fun. I don’t know what else you could ask out of a game like Dust: An Elysian Tail. I say this is a “Must Have” for anyone who enjoys 2D Indie Games.

reviewText: After I saw the trailer for this game I was really excited to play it, so much so my boyfriend bought it for me in an attempt to get me playing more PC games. Although at first I thought maybe it was a little too childish for my age, I quickly forgot that! Dust creates an exciting world that completely immerses the player and pulls them along. I found this game was hard to put down and from discussing it with others I found they also had the same experience. It might seem like a more Kid-friendly game, which is how one friend initially described it to me, but I find it appeals to a large audience of all ages.  I loved the story line and the art style and music. Perhapse I might sound too biased towards the positives of this game and not really elaborate on flaws, but as I said before this game is addicting and I don't think there are any major flaws that would really turn a person off from this game. I find myself going out of my way to complete every little aspect to perfection just so I can get more playing time cause I'll be sad when its finally done. =) I really love this game and if you're hesitant to buy I hope this review helps.

reviewText:
Dust: An Elysian Tail is a game that by this point in time really shouldn't need any introduction. The game has won multiple rewards, received much praise, and delighted many gamers, but how well does it hold up to all that hype?
In my opinion, very well, Admittedly the game does have its flaws, but when you stop to think about the fact that the vast majority of the game was made by one man, said flaws become much more forgivable. That said, the only note-worthy flaw with Dust: An Elysian Tail is the story, as it is rather generic. That's not to say that it's bad, but it's certainly nothing that you haven't heard before. However, that doesn't prevent Dust: An Elysian Tail from being a highly entertaining gaming experience. While the story may not be all that fresh, it does still manage to be entertaining, thanks mostly to Fidget, who will be your faithful companion throughout the game. You may have heard certain folks compare Fidget to Navi from The Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time, but I have no idea where they're drawing that comparison from. Fidget isn't some annoying creature with no purpose by to point out the painfully obvious and pester you every 5 minutes by reminding you of what you should be doing to advance the plot, but a fully realized and fleshed-out character with lots of humorous dialog. Without Fidget, Dust: An Elysian Tail would be far less entertaining in the story department, but thanks to her and her dialog/commentary, Dust's story becomes far more interesting.

Gameplay-wise, Dust: An Elysian Tail is more or less your standard Metroidvania" fare

reviewText:
I played through the game on Hardcore difficulty and enjoyed it. This is one of the best Indie games I have played. It has amazing artwork, great sence of humour and intersting characters. The story keeps you interested and you will want to know what will happen next, who is everybody and why things are happening. There are some references from other games (some are very well hidden) but not too hard to find if you use your head.

Some negative points worth noting:

I used xbox 360 controller to play and sometimes found that using analog stick to perform certain actions might cause you to do the wrong move. This is really annoying when you try to do trials where time and precision is crucial. I failed so many times when my character jumped instead of ducking and sliding or vice versa. I do however recommend playing with a controller even though keyboard and mouse works great, controller is still better.

You will probably want to play it once because once you know the story there will be no point in playing again so if you played on casual you are simply wasted your time because it was too easy and you can finish it in few hours. There are, however, 25 sidequestes which you can complete and you won't get all achievements unless you do them all.

Difficulty curve is not ideal. On harcode mode is really hard to start that will cause you to die over and over until you reach some levels or keep killing same enemies over and over. Later on it when you level up and get some items it becomes too easy. Simply be patient and you will enjoy the game without any annoying issues.

Overall it is great game that is worth your time. I spent over 30 hours and got all the achievements.

reviewText: A short, beautiful game that tells an unexpectedly satisfying, meaningful story. As a platforming beat-em-up, it's not particularly difficult or complex, but the strong vocal performances propel the game forward in an immersive, compelling way. Upgrades and new abilities are well-paced throughout, allowing you to choose whether you'd like to keep pushing forward, or backtrack for hidden treasures. I will separately note that the musical score is also extremely strong, with Hyperduck providing BGM that is memorable and very much a pleasure to listen to.\n\nWith so many games featuring a laundry-list of tacked-on features or grindy content filler, it is refreshing to play an exploration game that gets to the point by focusing on its core competencies, and does them well. This game was recommended to me, and I now recommend it to you.

reviewText:
Dust: An Elysian Tail
Don’t be like me and hesitate to buy it, just buy it already.

Dust is a game I feel like I have known about for a long time and yet has always escaped my grasp. I would put off buying it from one sale to another thinking I could always pick it up later. Finally during this winter sale I picked it up and after playing it for several hours I only had one question… what the hell took me so long?

Dust features multiple game mechanics and effectively make them work together in a cohesive experience. Firstly it’s a colorful 2D side scroller with vivid backdrops and a large open field. The combat plays like a responsive hack and slash action adventure game, including combo styles and magical attacks provided by your comedic sidekick Fidget, which in turn can then be combined into different flavours of multi attacks. That combat is backed up with a full RPG style level system where upon leveling you are able to increase various stats making your character that much more of a killing machine. And if that’s not enough there is also a full crafting system allowing you to collect blueprints, materials and combine them into new weapon, armor or accessories.

The game world itself features a world map which is traversed by selecting way points, taking you to the subsequent zone. Each zone is made up of many screens, each with a multitude of enemies, platform puzzles and secrets to be found. Shrines act as save points and teleporters, which enable you to fast travel to the entrances of others zones, for a cost. Stores can also found in these zones which work much like stores in most games, but in this case the first time you sell a material to the vendor it will catalogue it, and then every so often add more of that item to its stock allowing you to buy more of that item for your crafting needs.

As for the story of Dust, it follows the titular Dust on the typical quest to prevent all out genocide. At the start of his journey, Dust, Finds himself with amnesia, not knowing who he is or what his purpose is. It is here he is joined by a talking mythical sword “Ahrah” and the swords Guardian Nimbat “Fidget” who will help guide Dust on his path. The story itself follows familiar tropes but manages to make it feel fresh while still throwing in a few twists to narrative thread.

Dust is jam packed with mechanics and classic side scrolling mayhem offering a solid 10+ hours of gameplay with plenty of secrets, and familiar faces to collect. Don’t be like me and hesitate to buy it, just buy it already.

4.5/5

reviewText:
I started the game expecting a game like Guacamelee!, a simple scroller with little to no story, but after playing for 5 minutes I was able to see how amazing the game would be.

After some hours, and being only in chapter 2, I can say this is one of the best games I ever played in my life.

Being quick and simple, I'm going to puntuate it;

Graphics: Beautiful, incredible, having conversations in the game is an amazing experience, when I'm playing it I just want to talk with every folk I encounter, having fights is another amazing experience, Fidget's powers are gorgeous. 10/10

Sounds: Awesome, too. You can feel how the developers put all the love in the game, from the sound of a simple step, to the incredible voices and what they say. Every voice has feels. 10/10

Gameplay: Awesome, it can be a button smasher if you want, and it may have few combos, but skill DOES matter, depending on the combos you do without getting hit, you get more experience. Also, every battle is special, and I didn't get tired of it yet. In fact, I can't wait to start up the game again and destroy Fuse's childrens :P.
Saving the game reminds me for some reason to Final Fantasy X, which I loved as a kid, and it made me feel nostalgia, I really like the system. 10 slots and savegames in checkpoints. 10/10

Enjoyment: Since I didn't end the game yet, I can't say if it's replayable or not. I can see there are alot of secrets, in every stage you can see if there's a treasure key, or a chest, which will make the game longer.

I can't say anything bad about the game. I fell in love instantly.  BUY IT , you won't regret it!

reviewText:
Phenomenal. This game was an absolute blast to play through, especially for a genre I generally don't enjoy (this being the Beat-Em-Up aspect of the game, not the Metroidvania aspect of it). The world is highly open and fun to explore, with absolutely incredible atmosphere and a slightly cliché though very well polished story. The music as a whole is solid, though admittedly I only really found myself truly attached to a few songs in the game. It fits the world though, and it knows when to pick up and when to slow down. The characters are pretty enjoyable, each of which having their own unique qwerks and characterization to make each individual character in the game so compelling. It helps that the voice acting is honestly pretty good. The anthropomorphic-animal-type character design is offputting at first, but it really didn't detract from anything.

All of this is topped off by one of the most fluid, reactive, and satisfying combat engines I think I've ever played. Combos are given to you relatively early so you have plenty of time to practice using them, and I'd be lying if I didn't say I haven't sent chills down my spine for some of the absolutely insane stuff I've been able to pull of. Despite having one weapon (two if you count his companion Fidget), Dust has a huge variety of ways to handle pretty much every enemy in the game, and very rarely does mowing down hordes of minions ever get stale. The artstyle helps ludicrously in this department, making each hit feel rewarding and managing to maintain a long-lasting combo stupidly satisfying. This game has its share of Action RPG elements in it as well, with stuff like shops, level ups, and various equipment options to choose from as the game expands.

All of this made the game such an absolute thrill to play, and if you can manage to snag it for the deal I got it at (Three and a half dollars!? What!?), there's no question as to whether you buy this game or not. This game is nearly flawless.

Oh, and pretty much all of this game was made by one person - Dean Dodrill. Incredible.

reviewText:
Even though I am not much into furries, this is now one of my favourite games. And explaining why seems to be the most difficult thing I've ever written.

Let's start simple, the music is pretty damn gorgeous! There are only a few games that fit flwalessly to the game and are really enjoyable to listen independetly as well. None of the tracks gets annoying over time and they support the game flow from start to finish.
The story is well-written, and even though I normally prefer darker and more brutal atmosphere in my games, having a fairy taler occasionally can feel refreshing. And this one really does! The two main characters are really fun to take through the solid yet somewhat simplistic main story, their interactions with each other never fail to characterize them both and their bond. Some of the supporting characters are not so strong, though, but it didn't really bother me.
But the real meat here is the fighting system and especially the controls. I've never played a game with as tight control set as Dust. If you die, it's your own fault for making a balant mistake. You really feel like you are in control at any time. The system itself is really simple, yet it never got boring in my first playthrough. Every fight was thoroughly satisfying and the platforming, while I usually hate it, felt natural and fun to play.

The only bad thing I can say is the difficulty level, which is too easy for me. And the fact that after completing this game, other games feel dull and colourless... =D

Dust is easily the best game I've played for quite a while. If there is any chance you'd enjoy a good metroidvania platformer, give this one a try. I give it my biggest recommendations!

reviewText:
I don't want to finish this game.

I just want to lay down on the grass, and bask in the sunlight by a lake.  I want to make a home in the village, join the people in their way of life.

I don't want to fight anymore.  I don't need to figure out who I am.  I'm happy with just being Dust.  But it can never be like this.  I know that if I don't keep fighting, there won't be anyone left.  And that's the hard part.  It's a choice between me or the humble people of these lands, and the answer is obvious.




I hope they'll remember me.
Goodbye, Dust.

reviewText:
Stop saying it's a stupid furry game, damn it.

Dust: An Elysian Tail is a wonderful game.

It's a fighting platformer that tells the story of Dust, who goes on a quest to find out who he really is, along with a squeaky, cute, little flying companion and a talking blade. Is that it? Yes, and no.

While the fighting mechanics might be somewhat simple and feel a little bit too easy to win at, this game has much more to offer than that. The way the story progresses is amazing, and kept me interested until the very end.

Now combine that with fantastic graphics and music that just suck you in and fill you with atmosphere, brilliant dialogues featuring both epicness and humour, and spot on voice acting that greatly suits each character's personality. It's truly a work of art.

The only disappointing thing I've encountered was the amount of bugs in the game and even crashes here and there. But don't get me wrong - this game is nowhere near broken and definitely in a playable state, so if I may be so bold as to make a suggestion, you should really play it if you haven't given it a chance yet.

reviewText:
Note - I originally played this game through when it debuted on the Xbox Live Arcade and only recently had a Steam copy gifted to me.

In short, Dust: An Elysian Tail is the best 2D platformer/brawler story-driven experience I've ever had. Period.

Gameplay-wise, this game is very easy to pick up and takes a lot of focus to master.  Granted it's generally possible to breeze your way through the game by maxing Fidget's magic first, the melee combos and building chains is great fun.

This game is also aesthetically pleasing to the maximum, I couldn't fault someone for thinking this was a professionally animated movie (maybe because it almost was) for the beautiful character and environment design.

Throughout the story things evolve from very tongue-in-cheek tropes to the very serious and emotional later stages.  All along the way humor is balanced with serious moments perfectly.

As far as I'm aware Dust is largely bug free, and the options menu is something to take the ♥♥♥♥ out of even modern AAA titles.

Seriously, if you haven't already get your hands on this game.  It's cute, fun, sad and well worth the price even now.

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q6TLFbmYsrA&list=UU7_-PLIhjsEBwIQXqKxmNpA


Dust, An Elysian Tale is an action
platformer in a MetroVania style.
The game follows a character searching
for clues to his past, as he travels
through a country and helps its'
citizens.

The art style is beautiful and unique,
the UI is clean and efficient, the
crafting system is balanced, and the
merchants scale their gear as one
progresses through the story.


The platforming elements in the game
is balanced well and functions as an
addition to the game, as opposed to
taking precedence over other aspects.
As the player progresses through the
game, they face a variety of monsters
and atmospheres, keeping gameplay from
becoming monotonous.

The combat is fluid, and respects the
players strengths and weaknesses in
its' available techniques.  The level
design is done in such a way as to give
the player options in how they get
from point to point without seeming
linear, which adds to the enjoyment
and variety of the game.

Bottom line, the game is very fair; its
fluidity offers a sense of power to the
player, and it respects your time. I
can easily recommend this game.

For more details, see the linked video review, as this is a basic

reviewText:
Dust: An Elysian Tail is one of the best game I've ever played in my entire life.
For the record, this mostly is a one person work, and yet, it's way better than most of the AAA games released nowadays.

Artstyle, soundtrack, voicing, leveling, gameplay... Every single element has been shaped in a great way.
Add on top of that a bit of humor, some nerdy references and a classic but solid story, and you'll end up with one of the rare games that would deserve a nice and clean 10/10.

reviewText:
I highly recommend this game.

The graphic and music are just incredible. I have to say that it has the most amazing graphic I have ever seen in its plat former genre. I feel like playing a 3D game in a 2D game, which is kind of weird. The sound effect is pretty realistic, whenever I get into a cave, the game changes how the sound works. This is just amazing!

The game play is just good. If you enjoy hack and slash, this is right for you. I do not really get the story; however, I just enjoy slashing down foes. I would recommend using a console over keyboard though. If only this game has a multi-player system, Dust would be a no brainer pick on popular Steam games.

reviewText:
A Metroidvania with RPG elements. Visually, the game is amazing, bringing gorgeous graphics and animation, excellent gameplay. However, it has (so far) a clichéd story we've seen several times before, delivering yet another amnesiac protagonist, which is the game's weakest point (really, we don't need another of those)...
But that being just one low point, this game is still very much recommended, especially if you're a Metroidvania fan. As an extra recommendation, ignore Easy and Normal difficulty modes entirely and start playing on Tough for your first playthrough. It's the one I started on, and it seems to deliver a good balance, being challenging at times but not to the point of being unfair.

And if you need something more to convince you, it has Mysterious Wall Chicken.

reviewText:
It's so hard to believe that this beautiful game was constructed from the ground up by the hand of a single individual over the course of nearly five years of his life as a passion project. Smooth animation, amazing sound quality, beautiful artwork style and music tracks, responsive controls, and brilliant gameplay. This game is the shining example of what the indie community is capable of doing.

This game in indie game standards is nearly 100% perfect. The voice acting in the game is not as bad as people may claim it to be. Granted at some times during cutscenes, some voices are a little hard to listen to at times, meaning its not the best but its not bad by any means. The art style choice of the game may give some thick-skulled individuals on the internet a bad first impression. People should look at the art design as NOT being a nod to the furry community, but rather look at it as what the art choice was for some early Disney films like Robin Hood or Lion King. This game caters to several game genres including RPGs, Metroidvanias, hack & slash or beat em' ups, platformers, and even puzzle games.

There is no reason why anyone should have to miss out on this incredible expierence. Whether its on sale or at full price, this game will show you that its worth every last penny. There is only one complaint I can honestly say about this game. Though it has several difficulty settings, if you are familiar and well-aquainted with Beat em up side scroller games than this game can be very easy for some of you. The only time the game can be honestly challenging to everyone is on the hardest difficulty setting. Other than that one complaint, the game is sheer perfection. If you buy this game, you will not regret it.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

I don't really know where to begin with this game, i got this game from a viewer on my stream waaaaaay back.

The game got this really nice atmosphere that makes you want to play more, and more, and more. And some of the characters are so loveable (I'm looking at you Fidget) that it's hard to dislike them.

The entire game is a 2D platformer with hack'n'slash elements. Some parts of the game was very weird in a way with how the combat worked, but other then that it's a really good game.

Get it, it's worth every penny!

reviewText:
First, I'd like to say, if you like action, and I mean 'mowing down large groups of monsters with a couple clicks' action, this game is an absolute MUST HAVE. This is one of the most visually appealing games I've ever seen. It also gives you that warm, godlike feeling when you defeat a boss or flatten a particularily hard to kill group of monsters.

Good Features:
-Anime-style art and beautiful graphics
-Easy to master controls
-RPG-style inventory
-Gripping storyline

Complaints:
-Side quests open up new areas too often, and usually take forever to complete
-A skill tree would be nice

reviewText:
Dust: An Elysian Tail is a masterpiece, plain an simple. The world of Dust is presented with amazing scenery and hand drawn and animated characters accompanied by beautiful music. You take control of an amnesic swordsman on a journey to discover himself and every character you meet along the way is voice acted and memorable. Not the least of is Fidget a character accompanies you the whole game and provides much of the game's needed comic relief. There is a real sense of joy as you uncover more of the story as you play, and help Dust learn more about himself (as well as hear what Fidget has to say about various encounters).

Gameplay wise Dust is a 2D metroidvania platformer. As you slice baddies you earn experience which you can use to improve your stats as you see fit and equip and craft items to further enhance your stats. Over the course of the game you and Fidget also gain further abilities to allow more freedom in not only disposing of your enemies but also reaching new areas. Apart from the main story there are a number of side-quests as well as hidden arenas to test your skill. And it is all a blast to play. I would really recommend a gamepad to play, especially an XBox 360 Controller.

The most impressive thing about Dust: An Elysian Tail is the fact that apart from the music, voice acting and part of the story, Dust was created, programmed and drawn entirely by one man,  Dean Dodrill. So in a way Dust is like an American equivalent of Cave Story. I know that may sound like a stretch, but honestly this game has brought me a lot of joy and fond memories and I would highly recommend this to anyone.

reviewText:
The game is pretty fun, the biggest downsides come to basic design flaws that stretch over the whole game.

Graphics: Incredibily furry, I was honestly uncomfortable playing it at first but I got used to it. You simply can't make a deviantart artstyle without it coming off as incredibly wrong to people that are familiar with the internet. Other than that the animations are smooth but readibility can be a pain, there'll be ♥♥♥♥ all over the screen which will obscure an enemy who will go a little dark meaning he's dodged into the background behind you than molly whops you for half-all of your HP.

Gameplay: You learn every move within an hour, the rest of the moves you learn are locked away from you by story barriers and are only for traversal, so the beginning area will sit at 75% discovery until you're halfway through the game because you don't have the abilities needed to reach the chests that have like 1000 gold in them(you'll be swimming in gold very quickly anyway). So yes, the game only has 3 or so combos, fidget your little tails the flying furry pal of ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥ can learn more moves more than you, which is pretty great. The game is overall very easy, the entire game is very metroidvania(i hate this term but that's the closest thing I can think of to describe it) so that means big wide open areas with treasure and ♥♥♥♥ hidden around everywhere. Unfortunatly the areas are too big and your character is too slow, which means you'll be using your moves to traverse faster than wait for the move to cooldown than spin some more to go faster. The game has different difficulty levels that do nothing except increase enemy damage, this is where the gameplay flaws really come in.


The games just way too easy, despite only having 3 combo attacks, spinng your sword and mashing the fidget-kill-everything-on-screen button wipes enemies up like poo on butts. You'll start to feel like it's a chore and you're not really getting anything except gold and blueprints to craft new items(get a craft piece, sell to vendor, he catalogues it, buy infinite amounts) which are useless because you can run by every enemy and go into the next big area and get even better stuff. You level up in terms of strength and defense in a very simple manner, just go into the next area and get the good loot. I played the game on hardcore and it was frustrating, you're basically never going to be at full HP because the slightest hit will do half or more of your lifebar, so yeah you'll be destroying everything in sight, when you do get hit you will die. Yes there are healing items and you get plenty but it becomes a waste healing to full than getting nicked by an enemy that decided not to get stunlocked/staggered(this will happen a lot) and kill you. Bosses are pitiful and behave the same as enemies, so knock them into the air and destroy them unless they decide to ignore your attacks and kill you, turning a 10 second fight into a 2 minute respawn and die ordeal praying the AI just stops ♥♥♥♥ing cheating.

Music,story,everything else: It's all fine and passable. Story is get this 20 chicken feathers I'll give you money" quests along with a big main quest of "WHO AM I WHAT AM I FIGHTING FFFOOOOORRRR" story arc that at least has passable voice acting and nice presentations. Music is nothing special
date: I usually have it off and listen to my Morgan Page podcasts."

reviewText:
This game wasn't quite what I expected.  It's one of those titles where the enemies are pretty tough & do a lot of damage, but are slow and telegraph their attacks.  Your character, on the other hand, is fragile and doesn't hit very hard, but can attack with great rapidity.  So, your only chance of winning (esp. on the higher difficulties) is to keep your foes stunlocked  with an all-out assault, chaining hits and special moves together to never give them an opening.  As I've stated before, I don't really like fighting games, where you have to pull off specific key combinations with millisecond timing.  This is pushing things a little, but I was still able to use the combos they had programmed in, which is fortunately not that many.  This does limit the depth of the system and mean the combats can get very same-y after a while, though.

So, it feels kind of incongruous.  Your protagonist is basically a walking abattoir, chewing through monsters with gusto.  Except he's also supposed to be a rabbit, I guess?  And all the other characters are cartoon animals too?  The story similarly veers back and forth between srs bzns and light-hearted banter.  It doesn't help matters that the game is one of the worst offenders in the Cutesy Sidekick That Never Shuts Up category.

The art and animation are top-notch, considering this is a small-budget title.  It's not quite up there with the Odin Spheres of the world, but damn close.  The whole game is a bit on the short side, and probably much shorter still if you don't bother  hunting down all the sidequests and collecting everything.  That said, I had a lot of fun with it, and would recommend it to anyone who enjoys action-RPGs.

reviewText: Now, I'm not one for side scrollers, but chalk this up as one of my exceptions.  If there's anything this game lacks in, which in my hours of playtime I found little lacking, it certainly makes up for in its ... well everything!  The artwork is fantastic, the characters are all loveable, everything is properly balanced and the storyline is as rock solid as it comes.  But, those aren't what had me so enrwrapped in this game.  The emotional rollercoaster that this game puts the player through marks this as one of my all time favorite games.  The high and low moments that lead up to the ending scene leave the player cherishing all of those good moments and snarky conversations.\n\nThe only thing else I can say is to buy it, buy it, buy it!  Seriously, I don't think I could stress enough that if you don't already own this game you're missing out on a fantastic story.

reviewText:
This has easily been one of my favorite experiences from a download title from a small studio.
The gameplay is fantastic, I was having so much fun I was addicted to it actually. Fluid movements and crazy battles. A good variety of enemies, voice acting was really well done. The animation was just gorgeous.
The visual style mesmorizes. The use of swordplay and trajectory weapon is something unique to this game.
If you want a metroid fill, this is a good game for it. It is NOT a short game. You get your money's worth and more here.
My only gripe is the main villain, you'll understand if you play, but it doesn't detract from the joy of playing this game.

I can not recommend this game enough for action-adventure guys. Full price, totally worth it.

Have fun!

reviewText:
A beautiful, heart-breaking epic. I love the hand-painted art style and would buy it for that alone. But it offers an emmersive storyline and superbly satisfying combat mechanics to boot.

You play as Dust; a warrior who suffers memory loss, who is awoken by a possessed, talking sword, Arrah, who is quickly followed by it's flying, furry gaurdian, Fidget. Your adventure to recover your memory and take down a great evil takes you from biome to biome, presenting you with beautiful scenes and plenty of side-quests. Definetly worth every penny.

Breath-taking. I love no game as much. 10/10

reviewText:
Step into the shoes of Dust, another hero with amnesia, and travel a Metroidvania-esque world to slay monsters, talk to NPCs and find hidden treasures!

The gameplay is, all in all, rather simple. You run around, jump and kill a lot of stuff. You kill stuff by swinging your talking sword and employing the abilities of your flying squirrel-thingy Fidget, which sometimes bears resemblance to such annoying sidekicks like Navi from the Legend of Zelda.
The fighting itself is pretty simple. Your standard attack is a 3-hit combo, on the ground and in the air. Combine with your special ability and your sidekick you create some nice combos. You will also learn some new moves along your way, but they're primarily for traversing the world, which - in best Metroidvania-manner - has a lot of places you can't get through until you have the ability needed for it.
If you want to explore and get absolutely everything, you'll have to do a LOT of backtracking, but you can also use teleport stones that make it a bit easier.
Besides fighting and finding treasures you'll also encounter many NPCs you can talk to. Talking might reveal information and sidequests. You will also get experience from talking to NPCs, which I find a really nice little feature.
Crafting is also present. Defeating enemies or opening treasure chests might get you blueprints and material to craft the items from the blueprints. To make that a bit easier you can sell material to the shopkeepers, who then add them to their inventory, which makes it possible to purchase those materials from them. Quite handy if you can't or don't want to find them on your way around.

The game looks absolutely incredible btw. Beautiful levels accompanied by a nice soundtrack.
Not a big fan of the character design though. I don't mind antropomorphic animals in the slightest, but I just didn't like how many of them looked.
Also worth mentioning is the voice acting, as it's quite good. Not all were that good, but mostly it was very well done.

All things considered a really nice game with a decent story, good gameplay and gorgeous visuals :)

reviewText: After playing video games (both on consoles and home computers) for over 27 years, it's not very often I come across a game that actually impresses me; Dust: An Elysian Tail just so happened to surprisingly become one of those experiences.
