reviewText:
This game.. this game man.

Dust: An Elysian Tail is a very mysterious game at the beginning, of which then things slowly unfold and make sense at a fair pace.  You'll constantly want to know how or for the matter why Dust is here and why he's able to do all these moves and fight like a warrior.  Anything described story wise is a serious spoiler and you really, really, really do not want to spoil this amazing game so it's being skipped.

Gameplay wise it's a hack n slash with some RPG elements thrown in that actually mix well.  You have your health, stamina to do specific abilties, can craft items once you find a blacksmith, sell materials to a shop owner so they can restock up on them for you to buy later.  Obviously you level up too, where you can set in skill gems to tailor towards what you want to have on a high priority.  Still gotta put in some gems on the lower leveled ones in order to keep building up Dust to a powerhouse.

There's plenty of sides to do, things to unlock and discover, all the while enjoying the incredibly detailed and well drawn art.  The art alone is a very colorful and well done style that is impressive for a mostly one man game.  Almost could say it inspires some to get into drawing.

Don't let all the talking anthro animal stuff fool you, it's like An American Tail, movies like that of which could have been some inspriation to having these type of characters.  So it's not because the creator is some furry or furries in general, just don't.  Don't let that one single word sneer you away from this game.  You'll regret it, heavily.

It's hard to give this a 9/10, it's just so damn well made and entirely perfect, including the port to pc.  A quick note about the pc port. It's amazing what can be done if you take your time doing it, not rushing it like some of these major ass♥♥♥♥ companies do today with their half-♥♥♥♥♥ ports to pc from console.

10/10 solid, it deserves that well.

There so much more I could say; like how the combat is the most simple yet massively rewarding fight ing I've ever played, or how I couldn't stop playing.\n\n12/10 GET IT!

reviewText:
This game.. this game man.

Dust: An Elysian Tail is a very mysterious game at the beginning, of which then things slowly unfold and make sense at a fair pace.  You'll constantly want to know how or for the matter why Dust is here and why he's able to do all these moves and fight like a warrior.  Anything described story wise is a serious spoiler and you really, really, really do not want to spoil this amazing game so it's being skipped.

Gameplay wise it's a hack n slash with some RPG elements thrown in that actually mix well.  You have your health, stamina to do specific abilties, can craft items once you find a blacksmith, sell materials to a shop owner so they can restock up on them for you to buy later.  Obviously you level up too, where you can set in skill gems to tailor towards what you want to have on a high priority.  Still gotta put in some gems on the lower leveled ones in order to keep building up Dust to a powerhouse.

There's plenty of sides to do, things to unlock and discover, all the while enjoying the incredibly detailed and well drawn art.  The art alone is a very colorful and well done style that is impressive for a mostly one man game.  Almost could say it inspires some to get into drawing.

Don't let all the talking anthro animal stuff fool you, it's like An American Tail, movies like that of which could have been some inspriation to having these type of characters.  So it's not because the creator is some furry or furries in general, just don't.  Don't let that one single word sneer you away from this game.  You'll regret it, heavily.

It's hard to give this a 9/10, it's just so damn well made and entirely perfect, including the port to pc.  A quick note about the pc port. It's amazing what can be done if you take your time doing it, not rushing it like some of these major ass♥♥♥♥ companies do today with their half-♥♥♥♥♥ ports to pc from console.

10/10 solid, it deserves that well.

reviewText:
I am in love with this game.  I've never completed a game so fast in my life.  Every spare time I had (since I've just finished my exams and am now on my break) was spent sitting in front of my computer playing this game.

I love the artwork, as hand-drawn graphics had always appealed to me.  I also love the soundtrack, as it's equal parts mellow and epic, depending on the situation.  The gameplay is nice, easy to pick up, a bit hard to master (I've gotten quite frustrated at some of the platforming, took a lot of tries).  Overall, it's a really nice game, and I kind of wished it had been a bit longer, but it was a very enjoyable ride.

Also, love the story.  It's nice to see a break from the usual good guys always wins no matter what" pattern in other games.  I also love the little play on words

reviewText:
This game shows how you can still do some impressive stuff in two dimensions. The animations are wonderful, and there's so much fun to be had while slashing down enemies and finding loot around. The story itself is well developed and has several sidequests which make sense, and while there aren't dozens of them, they provide several hours of gameplay along with the main storyline.

Graphic (and sound/music) wise this game is really well done, mostly in a way that makes it fun to watch and play through rather than for sheer beauty, but overall all of the characters and the places are well designed and stand out perfectly. If anything, sometimes the gameplay is repetitive, but that has mostly to do with the platform design rather than with the plot or the level design (imho), as the 2D nature of the game has some limits, but in the end the game makes really a lot to overcome each of its dimensional limits.

For that matter, the amount and quality of both combos and movements of Dust make it fun to even just watch the character jumping in the air!
In fact, while fighting you can also count on Fidget abilities, and some rings/pendants/etc greatly improve Fidget's combat skills, up to a point that lets you draw the fight style that suits you the most.

RPG wise, this game allows you to craft several items but most of the crafting makes use of loot you can only find while killing enemies. That in turn makes for a solid system (as much as some backtracking) as it pushes you to play each area throughout, instead of buying most of what you need from a merchant.

Overall, a really good game and especially a really good 2D platformer (with rpg elements), a good plot and a fighting system that makes for a lot of fun.

reviewText: Absolutely phenominal.  Plays kind of like a sidescroller version of Ys (another good series if you don't know it; Oath in Felghana was especially great), has a relatively lengthy story, lots of sidequests (20~?) and if you like speedrunning, this game has a lot of tricks to master (currently mastering speedrunning myself on this game; dust storm op!).  10/10 would recommend to anyone.  Has difficulties ranging from Casual (easy, enemies do less damage amongst a plethora of things) to Hardcore (pretty hard, lots of things can one shot you, ai is much more difficult, and as stated a plethora more of things) and will keep you going for a while.  My only wish is that there will be a sequel of some kind, as the ending was very...open ended I guess (sorry I didn't mean to make a pun).

reviewText:
Now before i begin my review, i have to say something first:
If it weren't for an animated SFM video about Fidget, and my curiosity about why Fidget is so adorable, i never would've discovered this game. I'm so glad i did, though.

Now the actual review:
This game is what first looks like a MetroidVania, beat-em up, adventure game. But it's way more than that. The entire game is pure epic. The gameplay is intense and fun, the story is eventful and heart-pounding, the cast of characters are ALL lovable (I <3 Fidget), and the music is outstanding!

The biggest thing i love about this game though, is especially the story and the characters. All of the characters have unique personality (Dust is cool, Fidget is childishly cute, Ahrah is the serious one of the main trio, and even the each NPCs have unique personalities) The dialogues in the game are hilarious, and have many memorable and quotable moments. It feels like watching a movie (spoilers,  There are some anime-like cutscenes, following the original 'Elysian Tail' movie style. Both the movie and this game is the same creator  )

I love this game, i love the people behind it (one person doing the sole programming and graphics for over 4 years of development, plus music composer group, and voice actors)
I only wish the game had some sorta replay value (besides replaying the game in a higher difficulty), but overall, this game was a wonderful experience.

Get this game, it's awesome, i demand it!

reviewText: For those on the fence about getting this, Dust is a Metroidvania style brawler set to a beautiful soundtrack and fantastic animation. Anthropomorphic animals may be a problem for some people since this is the internet- but you'd be missing out on a great game. There's about 10 hours of content in here too - pretty good considering the price. If you enjoyed Super Metroid or Castlevania: Symphony of the Night, then you'll find a lot here. The combat in particular feels very fresh, and I'd say is more engaging than the systems in those two games.  In the future, I can see this game being considered a classic of its time. Give it a go!

reviewText:
6/10

Overall I enjoyed this game. It's fun, the artwork is beautiful, and the story really comes together in surprising ways at the end.
But there are a few complaints.

The big one is the health system. When you level up, you can choose to upgrade your choice of four things, one of them being max health. There is virtually no point in upgrading your maximum health. There is no natural health regeneration, and there are no inns or any other sort of place that you can go to restore your health. Completing a level does not heal you. The ONLY way is by buying health items from a shop. 20 health costs 80 gold. Sure, you can buy an item that restores 40 health for 160 gold, or 120 health for 480 gold, but there is no discount as you go up. No incentive to buy better healing items. No reason to increase your max health until enemies literally one shot you.

Moreover, the amount of damage the enemies do doesn't seem fair. They either do virtually no damage, or they do a TON of damage, but not much in between. So you are either just flying through an area virturally ignoring all the enemies, or you are using up all your health items in a five minute period.

The voice acting isn't of the best quality either, which the exception of the main characters. When I talk to someone, I don't hear the character's voice. I hear a person trying to do a silly voice. As I talk to more characters, I can hear what is clearly just a small handfull of voice actors trying to do a bunch of different silly voices.

Because of flaws like these and more, I wouldn't give the game a perfect score. But there is enough about it that IS done well that I will give it a positive score.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Gameplaywise, it's straightforward : you have one sword and learn several moves throughout the game. I thought this would limit the gameplay, making it boring at some point, but it didn't. The game is relatively short if you decide to do the campaign only, and becomes longer if you decide to do the subquest. You can find equipment to upgrade your sword & be more competitive in fights. The game itself is really easy, if you wish for a challenge, directly jump to the hardcore difficulty, where you really die easily if you gets hit (my advice : don't try to speedrun it, use combos & dodge as much as possible).

Graphically : it's a cel-shaded style plat-former, who really take inspiration into Don Bluth's An American Tail animated movie in terms of artstyle (they even made the same pun). At first I thought it would be a problem since I'm really not a fan of the furry genre (due to what the Internet did to it, mostly) but it really only took inspiration in the Don Bluth movie style and never try to sexualize the characters like you can see many games do whenever they try to add androgynous animal characters. So yeah, I really felt I was watching an old animated movie, with the same kind of message Don Bluth himself would be able to convey (about war, destruction of nature, etc...)

The story is cute, it's nothing great but it's very cute, very well acted, and I appreciate the voice actors' effort in the play.

One big plus for this game is the music : the music is absolutely fantastic, and one of my favourite soundtrack in videogame's history. Not even kidding.


It's charming, it's fun, it's pretty. The music is beautiful.

It is a wonderful tail... I mean tale.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Well well well Dust certainly turned out to be quite surprising, despite it's cartoony simple appearance Dust proves that it can be a fun and engaging experience. The initial story premise relies on piecing together the identity of the amnesiac main title character and what lead him to suffer from amnesia, honestly there's nothing hugely interesting about it. The standard story structure is followed and you meet some decent characters on the way but there's nothing hugely memorable compared to other indie titles on the market. However Dust: An Elysian Tail's biggest strength is its gameplay. Dust provides a nice hack and slash styled combat system that has RPG elements in that you can upgrade your abilities and wear specific items of clothing to increase stats further, the whole system gives depth to the game as you hunt for the best loot. Also the combat flows very naturally in thanks to the gorgeous animations that never hampers the pace of the game, allowing it to become rewarding and engaging. The only minor quibble is that it can sometimes become rather limited as you are tied with one weapon along with three magic assist abilities, as a result the game can drag especially if you're revisiting areas for a specific quest. The games presentation is stellar top to bottom with the voice acting being fairly good (Even if Dust himself can sound like he's trying too hard to be emotional at times), the background and character design's being stellar and the performance running smoothly without a hitch. Overall if you're looking for a fun action RPG to get into then Dust excels over many of its counterparts and can easily provide you with 8-10 hours of fun gameplay.

reviewText:
Phew... It's everything but easy to write a review to this game.
To be honest, if this game had been published from a major company, I might have been disappointed. But it is an Indie-Game (and the first one Noogy ever made), so naturally one cannot compare it to a major release.

All in all it is a really great game, hands down. ;)

Now enough talk, let's get to the likes and dislikes.

Likes:
absolutely gorgeous artwork and animations
an overwhelming soundtrack
smooth and action oriented gameplay
great voice acting
an absolutely cute and funny sidekick
funny innoendos about video game oddities (Mysterios Wall Chicken!)
unintrusive and funny 4th wall breaks
nice refferences to other games  (Mysterios Wall Chicken!)
perhaps not innovative but nevertheless interesting aproach on crafting and trading (increasing the trader's assortment by selling new items to them)
the Mysterious Wall Chicken!
Dislikes:
level grinding and item/gold farming is way too easy
Fidget becomes way too overpowered (I stopped using her powers at the meadows to keep the game halfway challenging, although I cranked up the difficulty before)
speaking of challenge: the first and the last boss fights were the only ones which were challenging to me, the latter perhaps only because I didn't use fidget
every health item stronger than the Mysterious Wall Chicken! is a bad bargain to buy (using 2 chickens heals 160 hp for 600 coins, the hot cocoa heals 160 hp for 640 coins, the birthday cake has an even worse cost-benefit ratio, so you end up swallowing countless chickens because it is the cheapest way to heal - but Mysterious Wall Chicken FTW!, so why should I care? :D )

About the story... well, I'm actually a bit torn appart about it.
Yes, it follows quite common tropes and is per se not that innovative, but it IS a good story and keeps you interested, if you alow yourself to delve into it.
But there are two major drawbacks about the story.
The first and the most disappointing is that major plot elements are revealed waaaaaayyyy too early. In Aurora Ginger tells you that you're dressed like a royal assassin - first half of the plot revealed, and shortly after someone tells you about a twin soul" - not sure if Fuse allready talks about it
date: but Lady Tethys most certainly does and thus revealing the other half of the plot.\nSo roughly after the first third of the game you can allready figure out what is going on
hoursPlayed: where and why" is kept a secret until the near end.\n\nThe second drawback about the Story is that "it seems to be a bit shallow". That's one thing often critizised at negative reviews about Dust. Well
voteText: i dare to disagree
helpfulPercent: hence the quotation marks.\nI think the story itself is not that shallow (at least not more shallow than the Halo-Storyline *duck and cover*)
votesHelpful:
but it is told in a shallow fashion. The arcs of suspense are boiled down to short cutscenes with only a few lines of dialouge and major plot twists are given away early and in a way as if they were only a negligibility.
So I say the Story would gain more positive reviews if it was told in a different way and revealed in a "different order".

Well
votesTotal: yes
votesFunny: this was quite a bit of a breakdown
commentsCount:
pointing out more negative features than positive ones.

But: Every positive feature mentioned outweights the negative ones by far.

It is an absolutely great game and mindblowingly detailed - especially if you take into consideration that this is the first game ever released by Noogy. Thats why I give this Game a thumbs up - I absolutely love it!

Oh and in case you haven't noticed yet:
I friggin' LOVE the mysterious wall chicken !!! :D"

reviewText:
This game. Is ♥♥♥♥ing FANTASTIC. Oh my god.
So it's an excellent, well-designed side-scrolling action RPG with a well-designed, well-polished combat system and awesome graphics, and it runs smoothly on even my garbage 4-year-old laptop. But the real selling point is the storyline. Holy ♥♥♥♥, the storyline. Riveting, well-written, YEARS ahead of what you'd expect from an indie action RPG.

Also, quests, a cool, new level-up system, and Fidget.
Fidget, the little orange creature seen on the cover of this game, is a selling point on her own. She's cute, funny, she's not just there for fanservice, she actually helps you learn the game mechanics and helps you through the storyline. And she's shaped like an ancient sex goddess. She ♥♥♥♥ing radiates sex appeal in everything she does.

Buy this game. Seriously.

reviewText:
I'm a bit late to discovering this game. However, Dust is probably one of the greatest 2D games I've played, and I personally had a lot of fun with the time I've spent on it. The fact that one guy did both of the programming and artwork by himself for this wonderful game is astounding and praisworthy.
The list below shows more specific pieces of my opinion:

Pros:
- Great artwork, the style is quite colorful and lively.
- Fairly large world with a variety of settings.
- Combat system is fun to play around with, high combos feel rewarding.
- Music is superb, fits the world perfectly and sets the tone just right.
- Story is paced well.
- Secrets in the levels are fun to discover and even feel rewarding later on in the game.
- Good length and packed with content for the pricetag.

Cons:
- Combat can feel a bit restricted after playing for a bit.
- Way too easy; the difficulty suddenly goes from super simple to sorta easy near the end. I don't recommend playing the game on anything lower than the tough" difficulty for anyone that has played any fighting brawler-like game before.

I highly recommend the game to anyone
date: it's well worth the price placed."

reviewText: I want to start off by saying that this is an amazing Indie game. The gameplay is smooth and fast paced - which hardly ever leaves you in distaste. The graphics are well drawn and keeps a consistent style across the entire game. Sound and music is well crafted also. Equipment system could see more improvements in customisation apart from purely modifying stats (e.g. affecting movement speed, giving your blade an elemental animation). The combat could see more variants in attacks and longer chain combos, including more types of projectiles to be shot. Story is captivating and the dialogue is humourous and enjoyable. This game can be finished in less than 10 hours if you blitz through the storyline, but unlocking everything will take a bit longer. Overall an enjoyable game - would recommend it to any platformer fan!

reviewText: I picked up Dust: An Elysian Tail today for only about $4.00 with the 75% discount from the winter daily deals. And let me tell you, this game is worth all of it and more. Humble Hearts, is a one man game company founded by Dean Dodrill, and Dean  spent four years of his life putting all his soul into developing this enticing work of art. And i love him for it. When i got into this game it reminded me personally of Castlevania, in the way the the hud displays your hp and just the overall darting in and out of combat to ensure you take the least amount of damage possible. Speaking of that, the combat is engaging and fast paced making for a great challenge, with parries, dodging, and even some combo abilities that make use of your adorable companion, Fidget. It is absolutely fantastic to see a single man put such depth, and beauty into a single game. Something that big tier gaming companies i think seem to be forgetting this days. The fact that i can go on side quests, buy items at a shop, and craft more epic items at a blacksmith. Even the leveling system is reminiscent of the rpg i used to play, very simplistic but still adds a great deal to the game. The soundtrack is vibrant in the mind and compliments the atmosphere and area around you very well. I would definitely consider checking this game out. Even after when the price goes back up to $15.00. It will still be a wonderful game that you should to add to your library.

reviewText:
It is rare to see a game like this be this well done. Dust: An Elysian Tail was made by one man, and the game has the quality of that you see with teams of hundreds working passionately on a project.

The game itself is a 2D Sidescroller inspired heavily by games like Metroid and Castlevania. You will find yourself exploring a fairly large open world, looking for items, money, and powers which will allow you to explore areas that were locked to you before. The aesthetic style of this game is truly amazing as well. The use of varied colors really helps the world and its residents come to life in ways rarely seen in games today. I would find myself staying in areas long after I should have left just look at the visuals and marvel at how breathtaking the vistas are. While it is cartoony, it serves the game very well.

I would also travel the long way through areas, ignoring shortcuts I had opened, just to listen to the music. The music in this game is nothing short of spectacular, with each area having its own theme that sets it apart from the others, whether it be a mountain pass that screams for adventure, or the haunted remains of an old estate with creeping terrors around every turn, the music sets the tone and atmosphere for each area very well.

The combat in this game is a blast to play as well. You will find yourself slicing your way through hordes of monsters, with a small but very versatile moveset that never gets old. It is actually possible to have a fight last upwards of a minute, without ever touching the ground.

Another point about the world of this game that I wish more games outside The Elder Scrolls series would use is the use of anthropomorphic animals. All of the characters are some kind of anthro-morph, whether it is a fox, rabbit, mouse, lizard and many others. I really enjoy this kind of thing, and it really helps the game stand out on its own, instead of falling into the tired fantasy traps of the overused elves, dwarves, orcs, and so on, which have been used to the point of being a checkbox for fantasy.

In terms of story, this game is a marvel. The plot is surprisingly mature despite the E10+ rating, and makes a lot of Mature" rated games look childish and infantile
date: and should last you around 11 hours depending on how many side-quests you do. I found myself genuinely caring for a lot of the characters in this game
recommended: while eagerly anticipating advancing the plot just to find out what happened next. During the story's darker points I was even moved to tears
hoursPlayed: which does not happen very often.\n\nFor $15
voteText: you get a game that does everything right
helpfulPercent: and will stick with you long after you have beaten it.\n"

reviewText: Absolutely gorgeous and incredibly fun! I haven't had such fluid, fun, and badass-feeling combat... ever. It's also just generally one of the best action RPGs I've ever played, with some of the most gorgeous graphics you've seen. If you're not a fan of the furry/etc. culture that the character design revolves around, don't worry... you won't even notice as you play (I'm not and I have enjoyed it immensely... the characters being animals actually adds a ton of charm to the game that regular humans wouldn't be able to bring) . You will feel like a combo-based-combat god even if you have no experience in the genre, but there is still a good amount of challenge. I highly recommend playing on the hardest difficulty (with the intention of trying to never die, i.e. true hardcore" or "ironman" -type playing) right off the bat... it will make the game much more rewarding and the learning curve is really quite an enjoyable experience.\n\nSome of the voice acting is the only thing I felt could use a little work
date: but it was only every now and then and you get used to it pretty quickly. For the most part the voices fit the characters pretty well
recommended: and the *entire* game is voice acted

reviewText:
I had high expectations for this game and after starting it up at least once I could confirm and justify those terms. Now that I've played through it and completed the game to it's full extent I can honestly say that it really is an enjoyable experience.

I'm seriously in love with the art style and the lush aesthetics which in my opinion add a lot to the immersion.. combat which is supposed to be one of it's best qualities is astonishingly captivating and dare I say it; visceral..? Add to that the RPG elements to give this game that addictive element of progression and the lust for exploration and you would be wondering what this game could possible miss out on - because from my POV everything else is just as great to say the least (characters, voice acting and the story which I really loved).

In regards to MvG, the character Fidget may very well be the only thing that could be considered a dealbreaker to some people. I for one couldn't imagine why because I think she's a charming and very lovable character but hey: not everyone is into 'cutesy' things so I suppose her voice and dialogue may rile up certain kinds of people.

Anyhoo.. Great game, I'm a sucker for it. For it's full price it's already a steal because I honestly think it's worth more. ◕◡◕

reviewText:
A beautifull, fun, awesome, emotional game. A gem of a game. A must play.

Dust is a 2D side scrolling hack n slash game. You take the role of Dust, a warrior who has lost his memories in a world ravaged by war, and his only hope is to follow the advice of a talking sword and his companion FIdget and set out into the world to figure out what is going on and who he is.

First of all, the story is great.The twist is not really what you expected which is a great, and overall the story is very good and keeps you hooked.The writing and voice acting is AWESOME.This game has the best voice acting ever put in a game. Period. Every line is delivered perfectly and...I just don't know how to describe how perfect it is.

The graphics are pretty good, everything is colorful and beautiful, and the environments are diverse, from snowy mountains to lava caves, and it all looks great.

The gameplay...great. The action is great and responsive,you don't have that many combos, but it's still very fun and has room for variety.And it's alwaysnice to see your combo meter rise, especially once it goes over 1000 :D With a wide variety of enemies to beat up, you will never get bored. Your character can also equip various mods and improve his stats, so there is room for customization of how your character will play as well.

Overall, this is a beautiful experience, one I will never forget.The story,characters,music, everything fits together perfectly.10/10

reviewText:
Phew... It's everything but easy to write a review to this game.
To be honest, if this game had been published from a major company, I might have been disappointed. But it is an Indie-Game (and the first one Noogy ever made), so naturally one cannot compare it to a major release.

All in all it is a really great game, hands down. ;)

Now enough talk, let's get to the likes and dislikes.

Likes:
absolutely gorgeous artwork and animations
an overwhelming soundtrack
smooth and action oriented gameplay
great voice acting
an absolutely cute and funny sidekick
funny innoendos about video game oddities (Mysterios Wall Chicken!)
unintrusive and funny 4th wall breaks
nice refferences to other games  (Mysterios Wall Chicken!)
perhaps not innovative but nevertheless interesting aproach on crafting and trading (increasing the trader's assortment by selling new items to them)
the Mysterious Wall Chicken!
Dislikes:
level grinding and item/gold farming is way too easy
Fidget becomes way too overpowered (I stopped using her powers at the meadows to keep the game halfway challenging, although I cranked up the difficulty before)
speaking of challenge: the first and the last boss fights were the only ones which were challenging to me, the latter perhaps only because I didn't use fidget
every health item stronger than the Mysterious Wall Chicken! is a bad bargain to buy (using 2 chickens heals 160 hp for 600 coins, the hot cocoa heals 160 hp for 640 coins, the birthday cake has an even worse cost-benefit ratio, so you end up swallowing countless chickens because it is the cheapest way to heal - but Mysterious Wall Chicken FTW!, so why should I care? :D )

About the story... well, I'm actually a bit torn appart about it.
Yes, it follows quite common tropes and is per se not that innovative, but it IS a good story and keeps you interested, if you alow yourself to delve into it.
But there are two major drawbacks about the story.
The first and the most disappointing is that major plot elements are revealed waaaaaayyyy too early. In Aurora Ginger tells you that you're dressed like a royal assassin - first half of the plot revealed, and shortly after someone tells you about a twin soul" - not sure if Fuse allready talks about it
date: but Lady Tethys most certainly does and thus revealing the other half of the plot.\nSo roughly after the first third of the game you can allready figure out what is going on
hoursPlayed: where and why" is kept a secret until the near end.\n\nThe second drawback about the Story is that "it seems to be a bit shallow". That's one thing often critizised at negative reviews about Dust. Well
voteText: i dare to disagree
helpfulPercent: hence the quotation marks.\nI think the story itself is not that shallow (at least not more shallow than the Halo-Storyline *duck and cover*)
votesHelpful:
but it is told in a shallow fashion. The arcs of suspense are boiled down to short cutscenes with only a few lines of dialouge and major plot twists are given away early and in a way as if they were only a negligibility.
So I say the Story would gain more positive reviews if it was told in a different way and revealed in a "different order".

Well
votesTotal: yes
votesFunny: this was quite a bit of a breakdown
commentsCount:
pointing out more negative features than positive ones.

But: Every positive feature mentioned outweights the negative ones by far.

It is an absolutely great game and mindblowingly detailed - especially if you take into consideration that this is the first game ever released by Noogy. Thats why I give this Game a thumbs up - I absolutely love it!

Oh and in case you haven't noticed yet:
I friggin' LOVE the mysterious wall chicken !!! :D"

reviewText: Well well well Dust certainly turned out to be quite surprising, despite it's cartoony simple appearance Dust proves that it can be a fun and engaging experience. The initial story premise relies on piecing together the identity of the amnesiac main title character and what lead him to suffer from amnesia, honestly there's nothing hugely interesting about it. The standard story structure is followed and you meet some decent characters on the way but there's nothing hugely memorable compared to other indie titles on the market. However Dust: An Elysian Tail's biggest strength is its gameplay. Dust provides a nice hack and slash styled combat system that has RPG elements in that you can upgrade your abilities and wear specific items of clothing to increase stats further, the whole system gives depth to the game as you hunt for the best loot. Also the combat flows very naturally in thanks to the gorgeous animations that never hampers the pace of the game, allowing it to become rewarding and engaging. The only minor quibble is that it can sometimes become rather limited as you are tied with one weapon along with three magic assist abilities, as a result the game can drag especially if you're revisiting areas for a specific quest. The games presentation is stellar top to bottom with the voice acting being fairly good (Even if Dust himself can sound like he's trying too hard to be emotional at times), the background and character design's being stellar and the performance running smoothly without a hitch. Overall if you're looking for a fun action RPG to get into then Dust excels over many of its counterparts and can easily provide you with 8-10 hours of fun gameplay.

reviewText:
6/10

Overall I enjoyed this game. It's fun, the artwork is beautiful, and the story really comes together in surprising ways at the end.
But there are a few complaints.

The big one is the health system. When you level up, you can choose to upgrade your choice of four things, one of them being max health. There is virtually no point in upgrading your maximum health. There is no natural health regeneration, and there are no inns or any other sort of place that you can go to restore your health. Completing a level does not heal you. The ONLY way is by buying health items from a shop. 20 health costs 80 gold. Sure, you can buy an item that restores 40 health for 160 gold, or 120 health for 480 gold, but there is no discount as you go up. No incentive to buy better healing items. No reason to increase your max health until enemies literally one shot you.

Moreover, the amount of damage the enemies do doesn't seem fair. They either do virtually no damage, or they do a TON of damage, but not much in between. So you are either just flying through an area virturally ignoring all the enemies, or you are using up all your health items in a five minute period.

The voice acting isn't of the best quality either, which the exception of the main characters. When I talk to someone, I don't hear the character's voice. I hear a person trying to do a silly voice. As I talk to more characters, I can hear what is clearly just a small handfull of voice actors trying to do a bunch of different silly voices.

Because of flaws like these and more, I wouldn't give the game a perfect score. But there is enough about it that IS done well that I will give it a positive score.

reviewText:
Dust: An Elysian Tail is a truly special game.

Done in the style of hand-drawn animation, while playing it I couldn't help feeling like I was back in my living room watching the Saturday morning caroons of my youth.  I did experience some display issues (flickering on the screen) but if you're like me, a child of the 80's,  and you experience it, I recommend pretending that you're just watching a well-worn VHS tape.  For me, that just added to the experience and even made it all the more endearing.

The story is compelling and you'll likely get sucked in and want to play this exclusively until you get through it.  There are some fun Easter Eggs that you can unlock as you go along as well.  Additionally, the progression is nicely paced between leveling up and the gear that becomes available throughout - I never felt like Neo until the very end despite rarely feeling like I was in danger of dying.

I chose not to 100% this game becuase I wanted to save myself some aggravation.  The collectables can be quite challenging to get (or even to find) but there is a wealth of information out there online should you choose to go that route.

Between the nostalgic feel and comfortable gameplay, I would recommend this game to anyone.

reviewText: Simply awesome. Dust has pretty much everything I want from a fun and entertaining RPG, and more. The story might seem straightforward at the very beginning, but as you progress in the game you understand that it's not as easy to predict as you thought. The action component, which includes combos with the (sentient) sword and magic, is really well balanced and extremely fun. It fits perfectly with the RPG-like evolution of the character, with experience points to spend in improving skills and even a crafting system not to be underestimated (you can put together quite the equip if you take it seriously). Add to all of this the beautiful sceneries, artworks, and the epic, EPIC conclusion and you'll get a game experience you won't forget.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
I highly recommend this game.  What first got my attention for this game was the artwork.  And it is beautiful.  But then I found it's a 2D 'platformer' game, which I'm not that big on.  However I did enjoy Castlevania and some other reviews here likened it to that game too.  Then I learned that it was almost entirely done by a single person - animation, programming, everything, other than voices and music.  So then I was very impressed.  Especially with all the other very positive reviews.  So with it being on sale I went ahead and picked it up.

And 70-some hours later I'm extreamly glad I did.  I still love the artwork, but have also fallen in love with the characters and the story.  Very enjoyable voicing.  I totally love Fidget (the Nimbat that looks to be a cross of a bat and fox).  There is a very serious and interesting story told, but also lots of fun and humor mixed in.  The fighting which you do a lot of was just fine for me.  Enough challenge to be fun and worthwhile, but not to the point of frustraition.  And the platforming is more exploration and puzzling than having to make pixel-perfect jumps, for which I'm glad.

All in all, if this game even looks a little interesting to you, by all means pick it up and have fun.  Even at full price it's not all that much, but on sale it's a no-brainer.

reviewText:
This game is just awesome!

The story is really good and was well told. At first you make your own assumptions, but not everything is like you thought it would be.

The characters look really cute and everytime you talk to a character and he tells you something about himself, you can feel the same feelings as the person. I could really empathize with Dust and Fidget. They're such a great people/animals.
The enemies were nicely drawn and not every enemy looked the same, which was very good, so that the game wasn't boring.

I really like the graphics of the game. This something childish, but yet mature is something, that not everyone can do, but the developers could do this really great. The background looks so lively and everytime you make a Dust Storm (Special Attack). The background movey, as if a strong wind would be blowing.

The game itself wasn't even boring and although you have to go to a few areas two or three times in a row, it didn't matter to me. I tried everything I could to reach these places or collect this chest and so on.

This game gets 10/10 points and I really recommend this game to players who like Fantasy and Action/Adventures.
If this review still hasn't convinced you, just try to play the game. You'll see what I meant after your first few hours.

reviewText:
Just.... WOOOOOW!

Dust: An Elysian Tail is a side-scrolling hack'n'slash game, and for me, an awesome one.

First of all, the graphics: they are just purely beautiful and colorful, the quality of design (maps/player/enemies) is perfectly looking like a drawn picture or anime/cartoon and nothing is ♥♥♥♥ed. Each detail is cured very nicely (foreground same as background and everywhere else on screen) and levels are all nice, even thou' they are all different (rain, snow, villages,...)

Now, the controls: they are easy to understand and handling is really fast (keyboard+mouse same as controller). Action time is not boring after some hours passed on it.

Lets talk about the music now: and it is great point of the game. its music and ambiant sounds are clean and perfect. You play with a quiet and magnificent music, zen and close to lyrical register. Ambiant sounds (rain, thunder,...) are very realistic.

And the last point, the story: Story looks great, characters are attractive and beautiful and Dust (the main one)more than anyone else, 'cause he does not know his past... What will happen?
Of course, there is a good humor in it (and also some litlle bad words :P) but you will appreciate close to all characters (except that Gianni, I still got problems to like him after the first met).

Conclusion:[/b][/i]
In other words. This is one of my new favorite games! A real love at first sight (and play if I can say like that ^^').

Really, I recommand that game if you like scrolling games with anime/cartoon animations. It is a very delighting game, a true pearl for eyes and you can just stay on levels just for hearing the music.
Then, if you play at it, just ENJOY IT! ;)

reviewText:
Dust An Elysian Tail. To put it short, it's an amazing game. The story is based on the character Dust who awakens in a deep forest with the Sword of Ahara and Fidget. Dust has no idea who he is so the three of them go on a adventure to find Dusts true identity.

The game looks BEAUTIFULL. No matter where you are. The forests or the mountains. The graphics look great and never hurts your eyes. The voice acting is great. The actors perform there job pretty well and the only voice I get tired of is Figets because she never stops talking sort of like navi from ocarina of time.

Graphics and sound aren't everything and Im glad to say that the gameplay is great. Having a metroidvania feel. You will destroy large groups of enemies with the occasional puzzle or platforming. Dust controls soo smoothly and attacks fast and quick. With Fidget you can shoot projectiles but with Dusks whirlwind ability you can make Dust and Figet extremley powerful and quickly defeat enemies. When you defeat enemies, you get expierience points and when you get enough you'll level up. This can increase hp, attack, defense and Figets abilities. I personally try to upgrade Figet first because dust storm is just op.
You can do sidequests, craft items, etc when your not beating the snot out of enemies which gives the game some replayability. But it doesn't give enough.

I don't really have anything wrong with this game. Except a couple of problems like one the game is pretty short it only took me 10 hours to beat the game. Two, its too easy. I didn't use a revival stone ONCE. And three I wish you could move faster than dusts regular dash attack. Because getting to one location to the next can drag after a while.

Thankfully, Dust An Elysian Tail is a great game. Great graphics, sound and gameplay make this a title worth owning. Definately get this game while its half price  right now thanks to the winter steam sale. I'll give a 4.5/5 to this AMAZING  Tail.

reviewText:
By far one of the best indie games I've played.  If you enjoy games such as Shadow Complex, Castlevania: SOTN, and Super Metroid, then there should be no reason why you can't get into this game.

There are multiple difficulty levels and the blueprint, item, equipment, and consumable system is rather nicely implemented.  The difficulty can be challenging at times but in a nice way.  It doesn't drive you to frustration like veteran mode in Call of Duty, where you're getting shot at from thin air.

I love the art style and music in this game also, and it is worth noting that it runs and looks very good.  The aspect of running up combos and managing your chains in-between avoiding enemies and not exhausting yourself is very nice.

Definitely recommend this game to basically anyone, especially if it is on sale, however, the regular price is very fair.

reviewText:
Easily one of the greatest action RPGs (and games overall) that I've ever played. It's a true masterpiece. The gameplay is solid and extremely fun (there's something very satisfying about being able to cause all of the enemies on screen to explode in a pillar of fire at once, which then racks up your combo counter). =3 The overall story is quite good, and worth playing just to know what happens. The graphics are beautiful, especially during rainstorms and blizzards. But what really makes this game shine is it's absolutely gorgeous soundtrack!!

If you're into 2D side-scrollers, RPGs, or just good games in general, you should definitely give Dust: An Elysian Tail" a shot. It's well worth it's price tag.

5/5"

reviewText:
A very nice game is every aspect.

The story is well written in my option. Some cases you can see what is coming a mile away and some you don’t notice until it hits. It flows and should you want to stop the main story and explore some of the side quest it doesn’t stop you. There is only I do believe 21 side quest in the game. But some take a while and others not that long. There is a Yen and Yan ordeal all around the main character, which makes it interesting.

Graphics have a neat art/graphical design to it. It is in a way kind of like an anime color to some areas bright and other dark. It is in I do believe a 2d side scroller is what it is called.

Character design was also very well done. You will find yourself most likely liking the main character dust and his side kick figet. As well as many of the side characters. They all have their own personality set to them, despite there not being that many other npcs in the game. It makes it worthwhile to just hear what each on has to say. When leveling up your character you get to choice from 4 major areas to level up. My only complaint in this area is the fact that you couldn’t raise a skill more than 4 times without leveling all the other skills. You had to keep all your skills within 4 levels of each other. So you can’t just max out attack or defense if you choice. You will also find yourself looking for better equipment most likely if playing on hard or high difficulty. It has the rpg element to grind mobs for money or items to upgrade or buy better and stronger items.

Combat is fun but takes a little getting use to if playing on hard difficulty. It can get a bit addicting in some cases. Especially if lining up combos of over 200. Take note no you are not killing 200 enemies. You are chaining attacks together on 1-6 enemies and possible moving onto the next group while keeping that chain. Depending on you attack damage you can chain bosses very high. Some areas you can run into up to maybe 20+ enemies but that is if you just run past everything and let it follow you.

Voice acting is done really well also. Some will say it’s nothing special, but I’ve heard plenty of voice acting in full games that just don't compete with this game. It has a neat art work

Replay ability is a little bit of a different story. There is not a lot that will change if you play and start a new game. Only one quest in the game can be changed, depending what choice you choose. Other than that, everything else will play out the same. Not that hard to get all the achievements if you’re looking to get 100% in the game. You could power run though the game in a few hours if you desired, but I took me time and explored and hunted down everything in the game. It took me around 18 hours to complete cause of that. The game is also easy to pick up and stop within minutes of starting the game with save points never being too far away.

Difficulty can range from very easy to very hard. Should you wish to play it for just the story but still enjoy the combat, you can set it to easy. This will allow you to die as many time as you wish without hurting your characters progress, story, are the combat you are in. Only drawback is you lose your current chain. Personally you need to set it to hard to even get a challenge out of it. This will make death permanent and you will be sent back to your last save unless you have a revivable stone. Which should you need to you can buy them from shops which have unlimited amounts.

You can see all the time the developer took into making this game with the amount of settings and design that went into the game. This game was mostly done by one person over the course of 4 years.  He needs a pat on the back for making such a good game. Really this is how good games should be. Over all this is a great game. And well worth the time and small investment depending if you buy it at full or on sale on steam. In the end you will definitely be tipping your hat to the author.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Dust: An Elysian Tail is visually stunning, the writing is excellent, and the control system's responsive. The world and the characters in it are unique and interesting. Voice acting's versatile and brilliant. Gameplay wise, the difficulty is perfect. The enemies are not invincible, but are by no means are cakewalk either. As in any good combat-heavy game, the combat system is simple, but flexible. I've heard many people say that the bosses in this game are too easy, but I still find them challenging enough. I don't think Dust: An Elysian Tail intended that the bosses be particularly difficult; I think they intended for bosses to be links in the story and chances to show off their brilliant game - and level design. For those who find bosses too easy, or just want a more intense expirience, you can always up the difficulty level. Magic spam is a viable strategy in this game, but in order to pull it off you need to focus 100% of the time. Personally, I don't think it's a problem, nothing in this game is broken or unbeatable. All in all, Dust: An Elysian Tail is a diamond, and a valuable diamond to be precise. This game is in my list of top 10 games ever made, and I would recommend it to anyone who is even somewhat interested in getting it.

reviewText:
with simplistic graphics and combat, this game has become one of my absolute favorite Story-based games.  Although this game is hugely combat based (it could be argued that it is a brawler) the story is very well synced with that fact.  I absolutely LOVED the story, from start to finish.

that aside, what really makes a game is what makes it fun, right?  so, yea..
the combat.
ohhhh the combat.
MY GOD!  IS IT GOOD!
This has got to be one of the best 2D combat engines ive ever had the pleasure to play with.  ESPECIALLY for an xbox to pc port game (its never this smooth).  although i find it hard to get into single weapon games, this one did it right by giving you a versatile arsenal of combos and manuevers that make even the cannon fodder fights really fun.  whats more important, though, is that the combat engine is SOOOOO responsive!  i can scarcely believe how much this indie title outclasses so many larger developer titles with its combat engine.
IT IS PERFECT.
there is plently of room for petty personal complaint, but as far as pure, solid fact goes, the combat in this game does EXACTLY what it's supposed to.  there are zero bugs with it.

What I truly love about this game, though; aside from the entrancing story line and exciting combat, is the art.  and take that word loosely, because im talking the whole spectrum.  The animation for character and level design is beautifully done!  The music is absolutely breathtaking!  this game itself, is a work of art as far as videogames go.  It was created and brought to life by one man over 4 years, and you can easily see the passion and talent in his work.

this game is much like the older castlevania and metroid games (metrovania?), and in my personal oppinion, if it had been released in that generation (give some modesty to the graphics and sound qualitly, of course) it would have been an instant classic.  There is no circumstance in which i can justify not telling you to buy this game at its current price of $15.  i would easily pay twice that price for a game of this quality.

One of the best, most fun games ive played in recent years.

reviewText:
I really enjoyed playing through this game.

It looks beautiful – the backgrounds and characters all look good and move really well, the attack effects look sweet and all together it is amazing.

I laughed pretty hard at a few points, most of them related to Fidget, but also Matti and a couple of the other characters. Genuinely sad moments too.

The level design is varied and interesting, and it never felt like a chore going back to the newly accessible areas with new unlocked abilities. The mini-map is also well designed for showing where things can still be found with searching for almost everything.

Whenever I had problems getting past something there was never that old school frustration with the game, but with myself. The difficulty is pretty easy on normal mode, and I’m planning to take a shot on finishing it in tough mode now to see if the challenge improves.

The full on duststorm spam attacks were very fun for the first play through, too! Well spaced save points, often entertaining voice acting (Fidget was cool!) and it isn’t like this is the first game I played with a two legged talking animal as the main character (that might well have been Master System Castle of Illusion).

Bought it in a Steam sale, but the full price isn't too high and probably worth it!
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Simple, joyous, fun in a wonderfully crafted package. This game has a great deal of heart and though put into it, both of which have been sadly lacking in most independent studios rush to market these days. Every part of this game sings, from it's simple practical platforming to it's top-notch voice acting, to it's combat. The combat will start simple and eventually have you flying through the sky hurling lightning bolts, throwing airships, and striking 800 hit combos. Yes!

A note: I held off on playing this game because of the setting. I do not generally enjoy this style of animation, or anthropomorphic animal protaganists. But this game's superior writing and acting absolutely won me over. I played it non-stop for three days, and now I'm sad it's over.

Give it a try.

reviewText:
I bought this game at a severely reduced price during a sale. If I had any idea what playing it would be like, I wouldn't have minded paying full price. $15 USD is a STEAL for a game this fantastic.

I wasn't 100% sold on some of the voice acting at first, but then I took a step back and realized just how amazing it is to have a fully voiced 2D game to begin with. Dust has voice acting throughout, for the main character, and every other character you meet, which really aids the immersion in the world.

The combat is fun and exciting, and even though it teaches you most of what to do, there are little quirks that you need to discover on your own as well.

The story (what I've played through so far) is interesting, and makes me want to find out what happens next.

PLAY THIS GAME!

reviewText:
To start off, I liked this game a lot, it had interesting gameplay and story.

Graphics 5/5

The graphics works really well with the environment that the story and characters were trying to portray. Each area looked beautiful with its paint style graphics. Also for the most part each area had something different to offer in the way of environment.

Story 4/5

I was extremely interested in the story. The story was pretty dynamic for how short it was. The main part of the story is Dust trying to figure out his mysterious past while he essentially helps people in need. Stories like this has definitely been done before, but for some reason Dust's story catched my interest a lot more then some others. With this said, the story left a lot of questions unanswered. For example, what was the background story for General Gaius? The story painted an interesting picture for General Gaius, but by the end, they just left General Gaius as the main Antagonist with very little explanation of why he did what he did. Also, the story could have gone two different ways. I think there could have been a possibility for two endings based off your choices. This could have made the story a little bit more interesting.

Gameplay 4.5/5

The gameplay was fun and rarely got boring. The game was a mix of 2d platform, rpg and action. You gain experience by defeating enemies and gain bonus experience depending on how high of a combo you can achieve. When you gain a level you are able to put one gem like stat point into one of the provided stats. Although levels were important it was mostly the abilities that you gained through the game that helped you the most in battle. The abilities you gained also looked extremely cool. At one point you were able to gain a fireball ability and if combined with Dust storm you were able to light most of the screen on fire torching your foes. With the right timing you were able to get a 1000 hit combo or more which was also very fun to watch and pull off. There were also many collectibles to keep you interested as well as challenge courses. I found the challenge courses difficult enough to get me angry after the 20th attempt which was fun but also a painful experience. The cameo characters were fun and sometimes difficult to find as well. These collectibles and challenges were not needed, but was a fun diversion from the main storyline. For the most part the gameplay was very well thought out but there were a few issues that I had with the gameplay. The combat was fun but did get repetitive at times. I feel like there needed to be more variety of skills to use, to keep the game from getting boring. The issue of repetitiveness was some what remedied by the shortness of the game, but I feel if the game went any longer I would have gotten very bored with the combat. Also near the end of the game I felt like I was overpowered. This may not be an issue with the game though considering I was probably overleveling while I was trying to get all the collectibles and finishing all the challenges.

Sound/Music   5/5

Nothing much to say here. The music and sound effects made sense for the environments and situations. The music sounded very good as well.

Replayability 2/5

Im trying to replay the game on a harder difficulty for the last few achievements but I find myself to lack the motivation to finish the game for the second time. There really isnt any thing different if you play it a second time besides the possibility to obtain some achievements and playing a more difficult setting. So a game plus option would have been nice or maybe a secret chapter where you can play as General Gaius and so on.

Overall this game was amazing and well worth the money.

reviewText: I am generally not a fan of 2d platformers; I got more than enough of them during the 8 and 16bit eras.  However there are some exceptions that are so well made that I can't help but love them.  This is one of those exceptions.\n\nFrom the endearing cartoonish art style and decent idle animations to the *truly* excellent sound and music design and decent voice acting (especially for an indie game!) to the well crafted gameplay, this is a top example of the genre and worth a playthrough by anyone, period.  Take it from a critic of the genre, this is a new standard bearer for which other 2d platformers should be judged by.

reviewText: You will often find, among gamers and critics alike, diverse opinions that state the positives and negatives of various games, with things such as the game is good" or "the game was too short" or "the controls suck."\n\nThis is not the case with Dust: An Elysian Tail.  I have been a gamer my entire life
date: ostracized as a child in school by the very people now addicted to Call of Duties and Madden NFLs.  I have watched the evolution of gaming from the 8-and-16-bit era of Mario and Sonic
recommended: the evolution of PC gaming from text based RPGs to DragonAge and Skyrim.\n\nOf all the games I have played
hoursPlayed: from casual Runescape to the intensely cerebral Europa Universalis
voteText: from the flashy twitch gaming of Smash Brothers to the thought-out fights of Guild Wars.  "Dust: An Elysian Tail" is by far one of the most defining creations in the Gaming Industry.  What makes it more spectacular and amazing is the story of a single man hand-drawing and developing the game from scratch over years
helpfulPercent: of an indie developer given a chance on Xbox Arcade.\n\nDead Dodrill has brought to us a game that
votesHelpful: in collaboration with secondary writer Alex Kain
votesTotal: and composers Alexander Brandon and HypderDuck Soundworks
votesFunny: defines everything we love about gaming.  He brings us back to the core elements of a video game.\n\nI can say
commentsCount: without a doubt in my mind
column16: that Dust: An Elysian Tail is
column17: by far
column18: the greatest representation of Video Games as an Artform.  If there ever any confusion or concern if games could be consider Art
column19: Dead Dodrill has proved us otherwise.\n\nNo amount of praise I could give would satisfy my love for this game.  For 17 years
column20: Blizzard Entertainment's Starcraft franchise has held a special place in my heart as my favorite game of all time.  Upon completion of this artistic masterwork
column21: I can say that this has changed.\n\nDean Dodrill
column22: Alexander Brandon
column23: and everyone else that not only made this game possible
column24: but brought it to the attention of the general public.  I thank you
column25: and I heartily reccommend this game for anyone."

reviewText: I literally just watched the credits roll on my first playthrough and I have to say that this is one of the most beautiful games that I have ever had the pleasure of playing. The graphics are gorgeous, the backgrounds and effects are astounding, the plot is very touching (play those side quests!!!) and the controls are very well done. The game plays like a dream. I can't get over the animations and the outstanding puzzle aspect of the world. It requires thought and perserverance to find every hidden chest and key, as well as all 12 of your friends!\nFor US $2.99, this was an amazing deal and an amazing game. Only 2 more achievements for a 100%, and with the sales and reviews (as well as the open ended ending!), I anticipate a sequel and will gladly pay for one!\nWorth full price, but grab it on a sale if you can. You won't regret it!

reviewText:
Ever played Muramasa: The Demon Blade? It's got fast paced combat like that.


Oh what's that? You never played Muramasa? Too bad. Buy this game and play it and you can say you've had a taste of fast paced side-scrolling slash em ups. The one man dev team even stuck some RPG leveling in here too. Even bothered to find good voice actors and writing talent. This indie game cuts no corners.


And don't give me that ERRMAHGOD TALKIN' WALKIN' FURRY FUZZY ANIMALS. When you and your small little bat creature side kick can turn into army killing powerhouses you have no right to complain.






Oh, and don't worry. I've got more playtime than a few minutes. I played this on the xbox arcade. I've probably sunk at least a day of my life into this game. It was worth it. Use a gamepad, though. Makes combat all the easier.

reviewText:
The game itself is alright, It could of used some more balancing though.

Don't take this the wrong way, I have enjoyed the game and I'm still not finished playing it. I just wish I could disable the specified things below to add to the challenge of the game.

- Dust Storm: Really this is the most unbalanced thing in the game. The ground attack itself is pretty helpful, But even that had the inability to protect you from behind. As a result enemies could still damage you, Which balances it out. But once you unlock the ability to use Dust Storm in the air, You're practically invincible. On top of this, It can enable you to skip areas and obstacles entirely by homing in on enemies above you, and being able to fly the to the top of the area. All you'd have to do then is find the exit.

- Fidgits projectiles: All this really does is add to the already unbalanced Dust Storm, And make it even more ridiculous. This practically disables the balancing of the ground Dust Storm attack, by enabling you to attack enemies from behind. Now you're immortal on the ground. Use it in the air, And it's even-more-so. The aerial version of Dust Storm already enables you to deal massive damage to enemies whilst not taking any damage, Add in any of Fidgit's projectiles and you can quickly kill everything that moves, Including some bosses. Really it's possible to beat the entire game only using this tactic.


Really these are the two major things, It's not worth listing the others. Aside from the issues I did enjoy the game very much, and I would recommend it to other people. I just wish we could alternate the controls and disable certain things.

reviewText:
It is rare to see a game like this be this well done. Dust: An Elysian Tail was made by one man, and the game has the quality of that you see with teams of hundreds working passionately on a project.

The game itself is a 2D Sidescroller inspired heavily by games like Metroid and Castlevania. You will find yourself exploring a fairly large open world, looking for items, money, and powers which will allow you to explore areas that were locked to you before. The aesthetic style of this game is truly amazing as well. The use of varied colors really helps the world and its residents come to life in ways rarely seen in games today. I would find myself staying in areas long after I should have left just look at the visuals and marvel at how breathtaking the vistas are. While it is cartoony, it serves the game very well.

I would also travel the long way through areas, ignoring shortcuts I had opened, just to listen to the music. The music in this game is nothing short of spectacular, with each area having its own theme that sets it apart from the others, whether it be a mountain pass that screams for adventure, or the haunted remains of an old estate with creeping terrors around every turn, the music sets the tone and atmosphere for each area very well.

The combat in this game is a blast to play as well. You will find yourself slicing your way through hordes of monsters, with a small but very versatile moveset that never gets old. It is actually possible to have a fight last upwards of a minute, without ever touching the ground.

Another point about the world of this game that I wish more games outside The Elder Scrolls series would use is the use of anthropomorphic animals. All of the characters are some kind of anthro-morph, whether it is a fox, rabbit, mouse, lizard and many others. I really enjoy this kind of thing, and it really helps the game stand out on its own, instead of falling into the tired fantasy traps of the overused elves, dwarves, orcs, and so on, which have been used to the point of being a checkbox for fantasy.

In terms of story, this game is a marvel. The plot is surprisingly mature despite the E10+ rating, and makes a lot of Mature" rated games look childish and infantile
date: and should last you around 11 hours depending on how many side-quests you do. I found myself genuinely caring for a lot of the characters in this game
recommended: while eagerly anticipating advancing the plot just to find out what happened next. During the story's darker points I was even moved to tears
hoursPlayed: which does not happen very often.\n\nFor $15
voteText: you get a game that does everything right
helpfulPercent: and will stick with you long after you have beaten it.\n"

reviewText:
I had high expectations for this game and after starting it up at least once I could confirm and justify those terms. Now that I've played through it and completed the game to it's full extent I can honestly say that it really is an enjoyable experience.

I'm seriously in love with the art style and the lush aesthetics which in my opinion add a lot to the immersion.. combat which is supposed to be one of it's best qualities is astonishingly captivating and dare I say it; visceral..? Add to that the RPG elements to give this game that addictive element of progression and the lust for exploration and you would be wondering what this game could possible miss out on - because from my POV everything else is just as great to say the least (characters, voice acting and the story which I really loved).

In regards to MvG, the character Fidget may very well be the only thing that could be considered a dealbreaker to some people. I for one couldn't imagine why because I think she's a charming and very lovable character but hey: not everyone is into 'cutesy' things so I suppose her voice and dialogue may rile up certain kinds of people.

Anyhoo.. Great game, I'm a sucker for it. For it's full price it's already a steal because I honestly think it's worth more. ◕◡◕

reviewText: Moderately fun side scrolling hack and slash plat forming RPG game. Played on the second hardest difficulty with a usb playstation controller and it took about 10 hours to beat it just doing the main quest line. About 2 hours of that was just grinding because I didn’t bother with the crafting system so my gear wasn’t that good. The enemies are not that difficult until you get to the last area. The greatest challenge came from the platforming as jumps were often very difficult to make. Your regular jump often does not reach high enough so you have to attack in mid air to get that extra height boost, but this makes sticking your landing in the right spot more difficult. You also often just randomly fall through platforms when you land on them which can be frustrating. I also had to restart the game on several occasions because I would just randomly fall through and get stuck inside of walls. The good thing is there are a lot of save points so even if you get stuck you don't have to restart that far back. The story line/dialog is kind of cringey, but I just skipped most of it. The environment looks pretty nice, but sometimes it is hard to tell what you can jump on or what hurts you as the background and foreground kind of blend in with the main area at times. I wouldn’t recommend buying this game at full price, but since it was included in the humble bundle 11 you can probably get it for cheap.

reviewText: After playing some Muramasa Rebirth on my Vita this game I was kind of expecting the same thing. Anime'd Disney anthropomorphic animal characters versus the painted monks, ninjas, and gratuitously proportioned fox ladies. Turns out while the combat can kind of descend into button mashing on occasion the work of one man, puts to shame, gameplay wise, of an entire team at Vanillaware. Nice characters, interesting story… and maybe a few too many childish things here and there… but overall an excellent 2D action/adventure game clocking at a healthy 10 hours.

reviewText:
Easily one of the greatest action RPGs (and games overall) that I've ever played. It's a true masterpiece. The gameplay is solid and extremely fun (there's something very satisfying about being able to cause all of the enemies on screen to explode in a pillar of fire at once, which then racks up your combo counter). =3 The overall story is quite good, and worth playing just to know what happens. The graphics are beautiful, especially during rainstorms and blizzards. But what really makes this game shine is it's absolutely gorgeous soundtrack!!

If you're into 2D side-scrollers, RPGs, or just good games in general, you should definitely give Dust: An Elysian Tail" a shot. It's well worth it's price tag.

5/5"
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: This was an amazing action RPG with a compelling story, a fair bit of action, and an adorable sidekick. I strongly recommend it, but have only one gripe. The game is a bit short, however when you look at the fact it was made entirely by a single person, it is still rather impressive. The end leaves just enough open for a possible second, which I strongly hope the developer is working on.

reviewText: Side scrolling action games are not my favourites, but this one managed to catch my grip, and to some extent my heart. With one of the most adorable character I've seen in any game, Fidget, a not world-breaking story, but good nevertheless, a easy to get into and go through gameplay, Dust: An Elysian Trail, is a very solid action/adventure/rpg game. I recommend it.
